title: Who Is Elena Ferrante? Supporters Say NOYB - The New York Times
author: Rachel Donadio and Jennifer Schuessler
text: The readers of Elena Ferrante are devoted  â€”   and fiercely protective  â€”   of that anonymous Italian author. That much was clear from the swift and unforgiving backlash after an investigative journalist used financial documents to suggest in an article  published on Sunday that Anita Raja, an Italian translator, was behind Ms. Ferranteâ€™s books. Many readers saw the story  â€”   which appeared simultaneously on the website of The New York Review of Books and in an Italian, a German and a French publication  â€”   not only as a violation of privacy but as an unprovoked aggression against an author known for female protagonists who use radical   to exert power over their lives and fates. In his article, Claudio Gatti, a reporter for Il Sole 24 Ore, an Italian financial daily, did not definitively name Ms. Raja as Ms. Ferrante, but he described financial records indicating that payments from Ms. Ferranteâ€™s publishing house, Edizioni   to Ms. Raja, a consultant there, had risen dramatically since 2014, when Ms. Ferranteâ€™s four Neapolitan novels became an international publishing phenomenon. His report drew broad condemnation in the literary world, with writers for The New Yorker, The New Republic, The Times Literary Supplement and elsewhere questioning whether an intriguing literary mystery needed to be resolved through tough investigative journalism techniques. â€œYou do an investigation into property for tax evaders, not for those who want to preserve their anonymity,â€ the Italian novelist Erri De Luca wrote in an email. â€œItâ€™s a serious violation of the right to privacy. Iâ€™m sorry for Anita Raja, who will now be forced into celebrity. â€ Running through the conversation was the notion that Mr. Gattiâ€™s exposÃ© was a sexist violation  â€”   yet another example, critics said, at a moment of intense debate over gender inequality, of how successful women find themselves bullied and demeaned by men. â€œPeople really went there very quickly,â€ Elaine Showalter, a retired professor at Princeton University and the author of numerous works of feminist criticism, said of the charge of sexism against Mr. Gatti. â€œHereâ€™s a woman who is not only extremely successful but explores womenâ€™s lives in a way that doesnâ€™t depict men very favorably,â€ Ms. Showalter continued. People may be seeing Mr. Gattiâ€™s unmasking of the author, she added, â€œas a kind of revenge. â€ Mr. Gatti said in an interview that he did not understand the strong reactions. â€œI wasnâ€™t going after a woman, I was going after a mystery,â€ he said. â€œI would like to ask the people who didnâ€™t want to know, â€˜Explain what work of art in the history of art has been ruined or damaged by knowing who the artist is?â€™ I can name many, many cases where the art is enhanced. â€ Hugh Eakin, editor of The New York Reviewâ€™s blog, which published the   version of Mr. Gattiâ€™s report, said the occasion for the piece was the forthcoming   release of an expanded version of a book of Ms. Ferranteâ€™s nonfiction writings, in which the author says she grew up in Naples as the daughter of a seamstress. â€œNow that an expanded version is about to be published in English, it seemed there was a legitimate occasion to inquire about the relation between the book and its author,â€ Mr. Eakin wrote. Ms. Raja was born in Naples, but grew up in Rome, the daughter of an Italian father and, as Mr. Gatti said in a deeply reported sidebar, a Polish Jewish mother who fled Nazi Germany for Italy. Ms. Rajaâ€™s husband, the novelist Domenico Starnone, has said in interviews that he grew up in Naples and that his mother was a seamstress. He has spent years saying that he is not Ms. Ferrante. Ms. Raja has also denied authorship of Ms. Ferranteâ€™s books. Mr. Eakin added of Mr. Gattiâ€™s reporting, â€œThough it amasses considerable evidence itâ€™s also worth noting the article does not make a conclusive statement. â€ (Mr. Gatti had approached The New York Times several weeks ago about possibly publishing his research, but the newspaper decided not to pursue the arrangement, which would have involved coordinating with multiple journalistic partners.) Over the years, there have been other attempts to unmask authors, such as Joe Klein, who wrote â€œPrimary Colors,â€ a roman Ã  clef about Bill Clintonâ€™s 1992 campaign, or Anne Desclos, who used a pseudonym when she wrote the 1954 erotic classic â€œThe Story of O. â€ But the effort to unveil Ms. Ferrante seemed to hit a deeper chord, perhaps because she has said in interviews that anonymity was crucial to her writing process. And it seemed to reveal a clash of sensibilities  â€”   between the journalistic and the literary, between those who believe anyone who publishes is fair game and those who believe some secrets should be kept. In short, a clash between the world of   reporting and the emotional truths of fiction. The publication in four languages simultaneously was â€œvery aggressive  â€”   more appropriate to the capture of a criminal,â€ the novelist Alexander Chee wrote in an email. â€œShe seems to have offended him by keeping herself private  â€”   itâ€™s like the literary version of â€˜How to Talk to a Woman Wearing Headphones,â€™â€ he added, referring to recent controversy over a blog post. Even some readers who admit they were curious to know say that they somehow didnâ€™t want Ms. Ferranteâ€™s identity to be made public. The editor of The Times Literary Supplement, Stig Abell, wrote a piece called â€œWhy the TLS Would Not Have Named Elena Ferrante,â€ citing the authorâ€™s right to privacy. Salman Rushdie took to Facebook. â€œI am Elena Ferrante,â€ he wrote. â€œIn the spirit of â€˜I am Spartacus,â€™ in the wake of the New York Review of Booksâ€™ tawdry â€˜exposÃ©â€™ of her identity, every writer in the world should do this now. â€ Not all writers shared that position. The critic Marco Roth said that Mr. Gattiâ€™s reporting was valuable, even inevitable. â€œConditions change for all writers once theyâ€™ve been published and itâ€™s naÃ¯ve to assume that Ferranteâ€™s pseudonymity (had it been protected) would have allowed her to flower forever in the brilliant vein of â€˜My Brilliant Friend,â€™â€ Mr. Roth wrote on Facebook, referring to the first of Ms. Ferranteâ€™s Neapolitan novels. â€œAnita Raja will now have to work this new twist in her life into the next stage of her work, whatever that may be. No writer can control or really has the right to control the conditions of her reception,â€ Mr. Roth added. Some writers invoked the rhetoric of sexual assault in condemning Mr. Gattiâ€™s approach. Alexandra Schwartz, on the website of The New Yorker, blasted Mr. Gattiâ€™s justifications for his unmasking  â€”   that Ms. Ferrante is a public figure and the public who buys her books has a right to know. â€œCertainly Gatti does not explain why he feels so free to interpret Ferranteâ€™s â€˜noâ€™ as his â€˜yes,â€™â€ Ms. Schwartz wrote. Some critics speculated on why readers were so protective of Ms. Ferranteâ€™s anonymity. â€œBy protecting her privacy, she protected ours,â€ the critic Dayna Tortorici wrote in a post on N+1. â€œMore than Ferrante herself, her readers have benefited from her choice. â€ â€œWe are as invested in her anonymity  â€”   and her autonomy  â€”   as she is,â€ she added. â€œIt is a compact: she wonâ€™t tell us, we wonâ€™t ask, and she wonâ€™t change her mind and tell us anyway. In exchange, sheâ€™ll write books and weâ€™ll read them. â€ Ann Goldstein, who translated Ms. Ferranteâ€™s novels into English, said in an interview that she hoped the latest revelations, however inconclusive, would not change how readers approached Ms. Ferranteâ€™s books. â€œI think people will read them the same way theyâ€™ve always read them,â€ she said. â€œI donâ€™t know how important the author is. Iâ€™d take her position the books are in the world. They are what they are. â€

title: Homeschoolers Revolt Against Republican School Choice Bill - Breitbart
author: Dr. Susan Berry
text: Homeschooling families throughout the nation are voicing opposition to a   school choice bill that they say will ultimately result in regulation of homeschooling in the United States. [Many parents who homeschool their children, as well as their numerous local and national homeschooling organizations, are protesting the bill, introduced by Iowa Rep. Steve King (R) and calling upon the members of Congress who are its sponsors to â€œleave homeschooling families alone. â€  School vouchers created by H. R. 610, the Choices in Education Act of 2017, â€œwould be a slippery slope toward more federal involvement and control in homeschooling,â€ asserts William Estrada, director of federal relations for the Home School Legal Defense Association (HSLDA). Kingâ€™s bill would first repeal the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA) of 1965. While many homeschoolers agree with the repeal of ESEA, the bill next would send all federal education funds to the states in the form of grants, which states would then distribute as vouchers to public, private, and homeschooled students. Estrada asserts the bill would essentially create a â€œfederal right to homeschool. â€ Section 104 of the bill states, â€œTo be eligible to receive a grant  â€¦    the State will  â€¦    make it lawful for parents of an eligible child to elect  â€¦    to enroll their child in any public or private elementary or secondary school in the State or to   their child. â€ Estrada explains: While this sounds good, HSLDA has fought  â€”   successfully â€”  for decades to make sure that there is no â€œfederal right to homeschoolâ€ because what could be created by a favorable Congress could be regulated by a future, hostile Congress. It is far better (and far more constitutionally sound) for education decisions â€”  and homeschool freedom â€”  to be protected at the state level. We ask our friends at the federal level to simply leave homeschooling families alone. Section 105 of the bill further states: The State shall distribute funds  â€¦    based on the number of eligible children enrolled in the public schools operated by each local educational agency and the number of eligible children within each local educational agencyâ€™s geographical area whose parents elect to send their child to a private school or to   their child.   â€¦     On an annual basis, on a date to be determined by the Secretary, each local education agency shall inform the State educational agency of  â€¦    the number of eligible children within each local educational agencyâ€™s geographical area whose parents elect  â€¦    to   their child. Estrada says the bill allows states to â€œtrackâ€ homeschooling students. â€œThere is only one way that states and school districts can do this: by requiring homeschooling families to register with them, and be tracked by the school district,â€ he asserts. â€œThis will be especially problematic in states that do not require homeschooling families to file a notice of intent with the local school district. H. R. 610 will require homeschooling families in all 50 states to register with the local school district. This would be just the first cost of â€˜free government money. â€™â€ In a statement on his website about the bill, King says: In order to receive a grant or voucher under my legislation, the State must ensure that the funds be distributed appropriately on a per pupil basis. Additionally and most importantly, this bill makes it lawful for the parent to make the ultimate decision between public, private or   education for their children. However, Estrada asserts it is not the job of the federal government to grant parents the freedom to decide their childrenâ€™s education. â€œThe Constitution protects the right of parents to direct the education and upbringing of their children, as the U. S. Supreme Court has ruled in its seminal cases of Meyer, Pierce, and Yoder,â€ he says. â€œFederal legislation to â€˜protectâ€™ homeschooling is unnecessary. â€ In an interview with Breitbart News, King says he â€œregretsâ€ most of all that a    meeting has not taken place with homeschooling parents prior to the uproar over his bill. The Iowa congressman says that while his legislative director has been on the phone with homeschoolers opposed to his legislation, a meeting he had slated with them may have been canceled due to his schedule. He said he and his staff have asked homeschoolers to hold back on their open criticism of the bill until he could meet with them. â€œAnd now weâ€™ve got a national thing going on here that didnâ€™t need to happen,â€ King says. â€œIâ€™ve been trying for the last several weeks to have a meeting with them, and Iâ€™ve said to my staff I want to look them in the eye and I want to talk this through reasonably. â€ â€œIâ€™ve tried to talk openly and do business and we havenâ€™t been able to have that meeting, and I regret that,â€ King emphasizes, still adding that he is surprised â€œthereâ€™s a nationwide effort to oppose the broadest, most sweeping bill that supports parents being in charge of their childrenâ€™s education that this Congress has ever seen. â€ He explains his view of the legislation: The objective is this, that weâ€™re watching as a nationwide curriculum is being established, and that nationwide curriculum, coupled with the money that goes to that, pushes all the public schools into that system, and eventually drags the parochial schools into that curriculum. Iâ€™m watching as our   values are being undermined, and Iâ€™m watching as western civilization is being deconstructed systemically throughout our public school system and especially in our universities  â€”   which we donâ€™t touch with this, by the way. The object is to put parents back in control of their childrenâ€™s education and curriculum and put it in a position where the public schools compete with the parochial schools. To have exempted homeschools from this, would have made the bill the target of homeschoolers, too. King thinks homeschoolers should participate in his bill for the sake of the new system  â€”   the intention of which, he says, is to save the culture of the country that is being destroyed by the public school monopoly. He continues: Theyâ€™re missing the objective of this bill, which is to put the public schools in a position where they have to compete with the parochial schools and respect and honor the homeschools, and let the states regulate those things at that level, not the federal government. States that are unwilling to pass a voucher program have to give up their federal money. So isnâ€™t that a much bigger goal for us  â€”   to put the public schools into competition with parochial schools than it is to preserve the status quo of homeschool? Homeschoolers, King argues, want â€œto be protected from ever being threatened by a state approving federal funds going through a voucher system that might tempt some of their people to accept some money that comes from the state and federal government. â€ â€œTo do that, they would not want to have parochial schools have an opportunity to compete with the public schools, which takes down our ability to allow masses of parents to decide curriculums, moral values, etc. ,â€ he continues. â€œMany parents canâ€™t afford to send their children to a parochial school, nor can they actually homeschool their children. â€ Wisconsin homeschooling parent Tina Hollenbeck, however, writes at her blog about the level of regulation Kingâ€™s bill is inviting in for homeschoolers. The measure, she says, provides for states to be â€œmandated to send information about all children  â€”   yes, every child using any form of education  â€”   to the federal Secretary of Education in order to get the voucher money H. R. 610 claims the states are due. â€ Hollenbeck continues: Of course, the states will want to report on all the children anyway  â€”   more children equals more money for state coffers even if some of us donâ€™t take it  â€”   but even if a state wanted to behave ethically in order to protect the privacy of home educators who refuse voucher money, they are not allowed to do so under this bill. Thus, any state that currently requires any sort of notification from homeschoolers  â€”   information that previously remained at the local or state level  â€”   will now violate our privacy by giving information about us to the federal Secretary of Education  â€”   without regard to either the 4th or 10th Amendments to the Constitution. And we can expect swift ( ) action from states whose homeschool laws currently require no  . They will assert that they â€œmustâ€ know who the homeschooled children are according to H. R. 610  â€¦     Karen Braun, a homeschooling parent from Michigan, also tells Breitbart News she is opposed to H. R. 610. â€œReading the fine print, it is clear they will make sure that states distribute the funds in a manner so as to â€˜ensure that such payments will be used for appropriate educational expenses,â€™â€ she explains. â€œAnd who gets to define â€˜appropriate educational expense?â€™ They do. â€ â€œThis isnâ€™t about giving homeschoolers help, or offering choices, but about giving the nanny state more control,â€ Braun concludes. The bill is   by Republican Reps. Andy Harris (MD) Trent Franks (AZ) and Pete Olson (TX). Estrada observes to members of HSLDA that Franks has clarified his position on the bill after speaking with homeschoolers: [W]e talked with Franks and his staff and they agree with our concerns about homeschooling families being included in H. R. 610. As a result, there is no need to contact his office, and we are deeply grateful to him for his commitment to protecting homeschool freedom from â€œhelpâ€ by the federal government. Here is the statement Franks gave us: â€œI understand the concerns of the homeschool community. My support for the bill only extends to vouchers for public school and private school students. If this bill moves forward, I would request that any language that would impose vouchers upon homeschools is taken out. â€ Breitbart News reached out to Franksâ€™ office, and his staff confirmed his statement to Estrada. The bill is introduced just as Betsy DeVos takes her post as U. S. education secretary. DeVos  â€”   whose primary areas of interest have been school choice and school voucher programs  â€”   experienced unprecedented controversy during her confirmation process from both those on the left, who fear privatization of public schools, and those on the right who have warned against regulation of private and home schools through vouchers. The school voucher  â€”   as a transfer of taxpayer funds  â€”   is a finance mechanism to create school choice and one that is associated with the highest level of regulation for schools that agree to accept them. If parents use vouchers to send their children to a private school or to homeschool them, that school choice may have additional regulatory burdens placed upon it by the state in which it is located  â€”   in the name of â€œaccountability. â€ In a 2010 study at Cato Institute, Andrew Coulson studied the question of school vouchers and increased regulation of private schools. He concluded that â€œvouchers  â€¦     impose a substantial and statistically significant additional regulatory burden on participating private schools. â€ Voucher programs, Coulson concluded, are more likely to â€œsuffocate the very markets to which they aim to expand access,â€ because state funds â€”  which invariably come with state regulation â€”  are directly transferred, in the form of vouchers, to parents to spend in an alternate education setting. Cindy Nicolai writes at the   Constitutional Home Educators Alliance that, for homeschoolers, government regulations are binding â€œstrings. â€ â€œ  and   home education must avoid those strings in order to retain our independence, sovereignty, autonomy, and most importantly, our freedom,â€ she explains. â€œWe recognize the value of that freedom and are willing to pay the cost to keep   home education unrestricted and free from government control. â€ â€œHomeschools are not threatened under this bill,â€ King insists, but adds, â€œIâ€™m still open to listen to viewpoints, but they also must listen to mine, and they have not done that. They should come and talk to me in a reasonable fashion instead of unleashing letters across the state and asking people to send tweets at me, send letters, and call my office. â€

title: Coal Miners Hope Trumpâ€™s Order Will Help. But Few Are Counting on It. - The New York Times
author: Campbell Robertson
text: Eddie Mounts, the son and grandson of miners, describes the past few years in coal country as a time of economic plague. Businesses closed and people scattered, he said. They went to Tennessee, North Carolina, anywhere work could be found. If they had to learn a new trade, they did that, too. The source of the affliction, he insisted, could be traced to Washington, to the Obama administration and to regulations that Mr. Mounts, 54, said were intentionally designed to shut down the mines: â€œShut them down and get them not working. â€ So he was thrilled with the news on Tuesday that President Trump was signing an executive order aiming to roll back some of those regulations. â€œIt may take a couple of years to catch fire again,â€ Mr. Mounts said. â€œBut I think it will. â€ It is hard to overstate the antipathy in coal country to the Obama administrationâ€™s regulatory approach, beyond even the rules that Mr. Trump has moved to undo. It included the Clean Power Plan, which would shutter older   power plants, and which the Trump administration is planning to rewrite, but also the assertiveness of federal health and safety regulation. Some saw these as mere attempts to bully the mines. It came as little surprise that Mr. Trump, who was flanked by coal miners as he signed the executive order in Washington, won Appalachia by huge margins in November. Hope that he can reverse the fortunes of coal country still runs high, as could be seen in the reactions of politicians like West Virginiaâ€™s attorney general, Patrick Morrisey, a Republican: This is a widespread sentiment  â€”   even if there is little solid evidence that Mr. Trump, or any president, can make all that much of a difference. â€œThe marketâ€™s going to be what the market is, and thatâ€™s whatâ€™s going to set the demand,â€ said Robert Stinson, who operates a small coal mine in the city of War, in southern West Virginia, a few miles from the Virginia state line. Regulations certainly played a part in coalâ€™s downturn, Mr. Stinson said. But only a part. Some of the fiercest coal country critics of the Obama administration have acknowledged as much. Robert E. Murray, an outspoken mining executive, recently suggested tempered expectations for a coal rebound. The Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, cautioned in November that the potential impact of a regulatory rollback would be â€œhard to tell. â€ There are too many other, more decisive factors behind the decline in central Appalachian coal mining, said Sam Petsonk, a lawyer for Mountain State Justice, a legal aid organization in Charleston, W. Va. â€œThe reserves just arenâ€™t there anymore,â€ Mr. Petsonk said, explaining that West Virginia reached its coal production peak 20 years ago, and that some of the stateâ€™s power plants had even been importing coal from elsewhere. Still, expectations are not so tempered where the downturn is most keenly felt. â€œWe just came into work one day and they said we got a meeting, and they told us,â€ recalled Mark Gray, 58, of the day he learned that the mine where he worked in Harlan County, Ky. was in trouble. â€œThey said we canâ€™t go on with these regulations, we canâ€™t go on with the way the governmentâ€™s doing. â€ A week before Christmas 2013  â€”   five years into the Obama administration, but well before the Clean Power Plan was even announced  â€”   the mine shut down for good. Many miners scattered to Virginia or other parts of Kentucky, Mr. Gray said: â€œThey just followed the jobs but the regulations followed them. â€ Those left behind had little to turn to besides public assistance. Mr. Gray, who has black lung disease, never went back to mining. But he doubts he would have retired so soon if his mine had kept operating. He said Mr. Trumpâ€™s moves might help, at least to some degree. â€œIt wonâ€™t ever be back the same,â€ Mr. Gray said. â€œBut I hope some of the jobs come back and fix up little places like Harlan County. â€ Gary Bentley, who spent a dozen years as a coal miner in eastern Kentucky, is less optimistic. Now working as a mechanic and writing about his years in the mines, he does not see a big turnaround coming. Blaming environment regulations is an old tradition, he said, one encouraged by the coal industryâ€™s lobbyists. But it ignores too many hard facts, he said, like the increase in mechanization and the abundance of cheap natural gas. â€œItâ€™s not going to make a comeback,â€ Mr. Bentley said of coal mining in central Appalachia. â€œBut you get a certain amount of desperation, where youâ€™re willing to believe stuff even though you know in your gut itâ€™s not true. â€ As much of coal country happily welcomed the news out of Washington, Mr. Bentley pointed to an announcement closer to home: This month the municipal utility of Owensboro, Ky. said its power plant, after 117 years, was going to phase out the burning of coal altogether.

title: Podesta Emails: Memo Reveals Clinton Campaignâ€™s Plan To Coordinate With DNC
author: Kevin Gosztola
text:
Following the publication of emails from the Democratic National Committee by WikiLeaks, chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz was pushed to resign around the same time as the political partyâ€™s national convention. She privately attacked the Bernie Sanders campaign and was fiercely loyal to Hillary Clinton. However, a document recently published by WikiLeaks clearly indicates the Clinton campaign had little confidence in Wasserman Schultzâ€™s leadership.
The document titled, â€œDNC Leadership,â€ is a memo attached to an email released as part of the â€œPodesta Emails.â€ It was circulated in December 2015, before the primary officially kicked off with the Iowa Caucuses, and it contains the campaignâ€™s plan to appoint a chief of staff at the DNC, who could work with them during the primary instead of the DNC chairwoman.
â€œThough we have reached a working arrangement with them, our dealings with party leadership have been marked by challenges, often requiring multiple meetings and phone calls to resolve relatively simple matters,â€ the memo declares. â€œWe are frequently caught in the middle of poor communication and a difficult relationship between the chairwoman and the executive director.â€
â€œMoreover, leadership at the committee has been slow to respond to structural challenges within their own operation that could have real impact on our campaign, such as research.â€
â€œJen Oâ€™Malley Dillon has entered into a contract with the DNC as a consultant for the general election, which addresses some of these challenges and provides a connection for us within the party,â€ according to the memo. â€œHowever, this arrangement does not change the need for systemic shifts at the DNC leadership levelâ€”to ensure that we have strategic and operational partners within the committee that can help drive a program and deliver on our general election imperatives.â€
The memo further reveals there were an array of â€œspecial projectsâ€ the campaign agreed to work on with the DNC before Clinton secured the nomination. They included â€œGOP opposition research, communications, and discrete data and analytics projects.â€ And from March through July, the campaign planned to bring on a chief of staff to â€œdrive the day-to-day workâ€ with the party until the convention.
NBC News reported in February that the campaign hired Dillon, a former Obama deputy campaign manager. The report suggested it was to â€œretool messaging and strategy,â€ and it was perceived as a response to Sandersâ€™s big victory in New Hampshire. None of the reports mentioned Dillonâ€™s role at the DNC or that hiring Dillon was planned back in December.
The memo shows the campaign favored keeping Amy Dacey on as CEO .
There were three plans of action for the DNC after the convention, none of which were executed because Wasserman Schultz resigned.
One of them involved neutering Wasserman Schultz so her role was â€œlargely ceremonial.â€ She would help with fundraising and serve as a surrogate. They planned to tell her the campaign would rely on Dillon to run the DNC.
Another scenario involved replacing Wasserman Schultz with former Michigan governor Jennifer Granholm, an ardent supporter of Clinton.
Throughout the primary, Wasserman Schultz constantly insisted she was neutral in her role as DNC chair.
â€œIf I wanted to favor a candidate, I would not be DNC chair and I would support that candidate,â€ Wasserman Schultz said back in January. â€œItâ€™s a pretty convoluted way to help a candidate when I have to actually function neutrally as the DNC chair.â€
However, Democratic Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii resigned from her post as vice-chair of the DNC to endorse Sanders partly because she witnessed corruption in the DNC. The party inappropriately limited the number of debates. Wasserman Schultz even disinvited her from a debate in Las Vegas.
Sanders repeatedly criticized Wasserman Schultz and the DNC. The campaignâ€™s lawyer, Brad Deutsch, condemned a fundraising arrangement between the Clinton campaign and the DNC.
â€œThe Hillary Victory Fund has reported receiving several individual contributions in amounts as high as $354,400 or more, which is over 130 times the $2,700 limit that applies for contributions to Secretary Clintonâ€™s campaign,â€ Deutsch wrote in a letter to Wasserman Schultz. â€œBernie 2016 is particularly concerned that these extremely large-dollar individual contributions have been used by the Hillary Victory Fund to pay for more than $7.8 million in direct mail efforts and over $8.6 million in online advertising, both of which appear to benefit only HFA by generating low-dollar contributions that flow only to HFA, rather than to the DNC or any of the participating state party committees.â€
DNC emails published by WikiLeaks revealed the party committee sought to cover up the fact that states were only permitted to keep a small portion of the funds raised. This allowed the campaign to skirt campaign finance laws and essentially operate a money laundering scheme to keep her campaign coffers burgeoning as Sanders consistently raised more funds than her with small dollar donations.
As POLITICO reported, Marc Elias, an attorney who advises the DNC and the Clinton campaign, wrote in an email to DNC officials, â€œThe DNC should push back DIRECTLY at Sanders and say that what he is saying is false and harmful to the Democratic party.â€
Dacey responded â€œI do think there is too much of this narrative out there â€” I also worry since they are emailing to their list (which has overlap with ours!)â€
At virtually no juncture did the Clinton campaign have to address their plans to coordinate with the DNC, which explicitly undermined the impartiality of the committee.
So long as the efforts to work with leadership of the DNC to defeat Sanders and the GOP nominee remained secret, it made no sense to say anything. It was much easier to let Wasserman Schultz field all the blowback from their unethical cooperation and replace her when she was no longer needed.
The post Podesta Emails: Memo Reveals Clinton Campaignâ€™s Plan To Coordinate With DNC appeared first on Shadowproof .

title: WikiLeaks: Confirms Hillary Sold Weapons To ISIS
author: Starkman
text:

Scroll Down For Video Below! In an interview with Democracy Now, Wikileaksâ€™ Julian Assange is now stating that 1,700 emails contained in the Clinton cache directly connect Hillary to Libya to Syria, and directly to Al Qaeda and ISIS.
JUAN GONZÃLEZ: Julian, I want to mention something else. In March, you launched a searchable archive for over 30,000 emails and email attachments sent to and from Hillary Clintonâ€™s private email server while she was secretary of state. The 50,547 pages of documents span the time from June 2010 to August 2014; 7,500 of the documents were sent by Hillary Clinton herself. The emails were made available in the form of thousands of PDFs by the U.S. State Department as the result of a Freedom of Information Act request. Why did you do this, and whatâ€™s the importance, from your perspective, of being able to create a searchable base?
JULIAN ASSANGE: Well, WikiLeaks has become the rebel library of Alexandria. It is the single most significant collection of information that doesnâ€™t exist elsewhere, in a searchable, accessible, citable form, about how modern institutions actually behave. And itâ€™s gone on to set people free from prison, where documents have been used in their court cases; hold the CIA accountable for renditions programs; feed into election cycles, which have resulted in the termination of, in some caseâ€”or contributed to the termination of governments, in some cases, taken the heads of intelligence agencies, ministers of defense and so on. So, you know, our civilizations can only be as good as our knowledge of what our civilisation is. We canâ€™t possibly hope to reform that which we do not understand.
So, those Hillary Clinton emails, they connect together with the cables that we have published of Hillary Clinton, creating a rich picture of how Hillary Clinton performs in office, but, more broadly, how the U.S. Department of State operates. So, for example, the disastrous, absolutely disastrous intervention in Libya, the destruction of the Gaddafi government, which led to the occupation of ISIS of large segments of that country, weapons flows going over to Syria, being pushed by Hillary Clinton, into jihadists within Syria, including ISIS, thatâ€™s there in those emails. Thereâ€™s more than 1,700 emails in Hillary Clintonâ€™s collection, that we have released, just about Libya alone.
It appears that Hillary Clinton committed perjury, just like her husband was caught doing as President.

title: Furious parents slam â€˜damagingâ€™ BBC sex change show aimed at six-year-olds
author: wmw_admin
text:
By wmw_admin on October 31, 2016 Sanchez Manning â€” Daily Mail Oct 29, 2016 
The BBC has been accused of acting recklessly after targeting children as young as six with a programme about a schoolboy who takes sex-change drugs. 
Parents are angry that the show, available on the CBBC website, features a transgender storyline inappropriate for their children. 
And concerned campaigners said it could â€˜sow the seeds of confusionâ€™ in young minds. The programme, Just A Girl, depicts an 11-year-oldâ€™s struggle to get hormones that stunt puberty, making it easier to have sex-change surgery in the future. 
One mother, writing on the Mumsnet website, said her daughter had become worried after seeing the video. She said her girl, who likes wearing boysâ€™ clothes and playing football, had â€˜asked me, anxiously, if that means she was a boyâ€™. 
Tory MP Peter Bone said: â€˜It beggars belief that the BBC is making this programme freely available to children as young as six. I entirely share the anger of parents who just want to let children be children. 
â€˜It is completely inappropriate for such material to be on the CBBC website and I shall be writing to BBC bosses to demand they take it down as soon as possible.â€™ 
Former Culture Secretary Maria Miller voiced her concerns over the BBC tackling the subject in â€˜an age-appropriate wayâ€™, saying such issues should be raised â€˜where children can have support from parentsâ€™. 
And Tory MP Julian Brazier said: â€˜This programme is very disappointing and inappropriate. Children are very impressionable and this is going to confuse and worry them.â€™ 
Family campaigner Norman Wells said: â€˜It is irresponsible of the BBC to introduce impressionable children as young as six to the idea that they can choose to be something other than their biological sex.â€™ 
Just A Girl is the fictional video diary of a child who calls herself â€˜Amyâ€™ and dresses as a girl. It is hosted on the CBBC website, aimed at children aged between six and 12. 
In the half-hour programme, Amy â€“ played by an actress â€“ reveals she was born a boy called Ben but has already started using puberty-halting drugs. 
Such hypothalamic blockers provoked a furore two years ago when The Mail on Sunday revealed an NHS clinic was willing to give them to children as young as nine. 
Critics cited research claiming that most teenagers confused about their gender never go through with surgery, with many realising they are gay. The BBC row comes amid growing controversy over gender issues, fuelled by a number of high-profile cases. In one, a Christian couple were threatened with having their 14-year-old daughter taken away because they oppose her plans to become a boy. 
In another, a seven-year-old boy was ordered to be removed from his motherâ€™s care as â€˜she was raising him as femaleâ€™, causing him â€˜a great deal of emotional harmâ€™. 
In Just A Girl, Amy says: â€˜When I was born, Mum said Dad was so pleased that he had a boy to take to the football. But Mum knew I was different. She realised early on that I was born in the wrong body.â€™ 
She adds: â€˜My Mum supported me when I did a PowerPoint presentation to my class about transitioning and that I wasnâ€™t going to come to school in boysâ€™ clothes any more, but girlsâ€™ clothes. I wasnâ€™t Ben, I was Amy.â€™ 
Later Amy is shown telling a friend, Josh â€“ a boy who wants to be recognised as a girl â€“ that she is on hormone blockers, saying it took â€˜agesâ€™ to get them after â€˜loads of tests and talks at the clinicâ€™. â€˜Once they realised I was trans for real, [I] got them,â€™ she says. In another entry, Amy tells viewers she has developed a crush on a boy called Liam, but confides: â€˜Liam thinks Iâ€™m just a girl, but Iâ€™m not. Iâ€™m trans. And whatâ€™s he going to say if he finds out? Stop being my friend? Why? Iâ€™m still me, arenâ€™t I?â€™ 
Child psychotherapist Dr Dilys Daws said the programme could confuse children. She said that, while it was natural for youngsters to wonder what it would be like to be the opposite sex, the BBC was irresponsible to feature the â€˜extremeâ€™ step of gender change for six-year-olds because they were too young to grapple with such issues. 
The programme generated hundreds of comments on Mumsnet. 
One mother, who said her seven-year-old had watched the show, asked: â€˜Am I being unreasonable to think this is an inappropriate topic for a young age group?â€™ 
Another replied: â€˜Donâ€™t think this is remotely suitable for a seven-year-old. To start suggesting that children can be transgender when theyâ€™re far too young to actually have a gender is reckless and damaging. A small boy who is told that he can become a girl may take this as meaning that sex changes are possible, that sometime in the future heâ€™ll wake up with a girlâ€™s body.â€™ 
Another user added: â€˜I donâ€™t think hormone therapy should be normalised any more than 12-year-olds drinking or doing recreational drugs should be normalised.â€™ 
Other critics slammed the BBC. Mr Wells, director of the Family Education Trust, said: â€˜The more we promote the idea that a boy can be born into a girlâ€™s body and a girl can be born into a boyâ€™s body, and that drugs and surgery can put things right, the more children will become utterly confused. Respecting and preserving a childâ€™s birth sex should be seen as a child protection issue.â€™ 
But some parents on Mumsnet were more positive. One wrote: â€˜I donâ€™t believe there is â€œtoo youngâ€ for stuff like this. The earlier you teach your children that everyone is different and that nobody is â€œnormalâ€ the better.â€™ 
Dr Polly Carmichael, a clinical psychologist specialising in transgender children, said: â€˜Raising awareness of these issues is the best way to challenge stigma and discrimination associated with identity issues. Programmes like Just A Girl can contribute to a healthy and informed public discussion.â€™ 
The BBC said: â€˜Just A Girl is about a fictional transgender character trying to make sense of the world, deal with bullying and work out how to keep her friends, which are universal themes that many children relate to, and which has had a positive response from our audience. 
â€˜CBBC aims to reflect true life, providing content that mirrors the lives of as many UK children as possible.â€™

title: DONALD TRUMP CLOSES GAP WITH HILLARY CLINTON IN MICHIGAN
author: Iron Sheik
text:
Home â€º POLITICS | US NEWS â€º DONALD TRUMP CLOSES GAP WITH HILLARY CLINTON IN MICHIGAN DONALD TRUMP CLOSES GAP WITH HILLARY CLINTON IN MICHIGAN 0 SHARES 
[10/27/16] Republican nominee Donald Trump is now within striking distance of Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in Michigan, a state that has not voted for a Republican presidential candidate since 1988. 
In the latest Fox 2 Detroit/Mitchell Poll , Trump trails Clinton by just six points. In the four-way poll, Clinton received 48 percent, Trump received 42 percent, Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson received 4.5 percent, and Green Party candidate Jill Stein received 1 percent. Clinton led Trump 50 percent to 44 percent, in the head-to-head. 
Fifty-nine percent of polled voters said that jobs and the economy are the most important issues, while 29 percent said that national defense and terrorism were most important. 
A Detroit Free Press/WXYZ-TV poll places Clinton ahead of Trump by 7 points, which is still a significant narrowing compared to previous polls. 
Public backlash against trade deals like President Barack Obamaâ€™s Tran-Pacific Partnership â€“ a deal that Clinton once called â€œthe gold standard in trade agreementsâ€â€“ was so fierce that Clinton changed her tune during the Democratic primary where she was defeated by Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders. 
â€œAcross Michigan, Republicans are coming home and taking a united stand against Hillary Clintonâ€™s radical, open-borders agenda and plan to double-down on failed Obama policies, such as Obamacare. We are also seeing independents, Democrats and union workers saying no to Clintonâ€™s special interest driven agenda, and yes to Mr. Trumpâ€™s plan to put America first,â€ Tim Lineberger, communications director for Trumpâ€™s Michigan campaign team told The Daily Caller News Foundation. 
â€œHard working Americans will be voting for change in November because they feel like the system is rigged against them, and they know that Clinton and her cohorts are the ones rigging it,â€ Lineberger added. 
Clinton was previously caught on tape telling a group of foreign bankers that her dream was a â€œhemispheric common market, with open trade and open borders.â€ Trump is also hoping to capitalize on the governmentâ€™s recent report, stating that the price of Obamacare premiums are expected to increase an average of 22 percent. title: â€˜Iâ€™ve Become a Racistâ€™: Migrant Wave Unleashes Danish Tensions Over Identity - The New York Times
author: David Zucchino
text: TAARNBY, Denmark  â€”   Johnny Christensen, a stout and   retired bank employee, always thought of himself as sympathetic to people fleeing war and welcoming to immigrants. But after more than 36, 000 mostly Muslim asylum seekers poured into Denmark over the past two years, Mr. Christensen, 65, said, â€œIâ€™ve become a racist. â€ He believes these new migrants are draining Denmarkâ€™s cherished   system but failing to adapt to its customs. â€œJust kick them out,â€ he said, unleashing a mighty kick at an imaginary target on a suburban sidewalk. â€œThese Muslims want to keep their own culture, but we have our own rules here and everyone must follow them. â€ Denmark, a small and orderly nation with a progressive   is built on a social covenant: In return for some of the worldâ€™s highest wages and benefits, people are expected to work hard and pay into the system. Newcomers must quickly learn Danish  â€”   and adapt to norms like keeping tidy gardens and riding bicycles. The country had little experience with immigrants until 1967, when the first â€œguest workersâ€ were invited from Turkey, Pakistan and what was then Yugoslavia. Its 5. 7 million people remain overwhelmingly native born, though the percentage has dropped to 88 today from 97 in 1980. Bo Lidegaard, a prominent historian, said many Danes feel strongly that â€œwe are a multiethnic society today, and we have to realize it  â€”   but we are not and should never become a multicultural society. â€ The recent influx pales next to the one million migrants absorbed into Germany or the 163, 000 into Sweden last year, but the pace shocked this stable, homogeneous country. The   government has backed harsh measures targeting migrants, hate speech has spiked, and the   Danish Peopleâ€™s Party is now the second largest in Parliament. Some of the same hostilities were reflected this weekend in Germany, where voters in Chancellor Angela Merkelâ€™s home state embraced   candidates  â€”   an emphatic rejection of her refugee policy. There is new tension between Danes still opening their arms and a resurgent right wing that seeks to ban all Muslims and shut Denmark off from Europe. Mr. Christensen, the retired banker, supports emerging proposals for his country to follow Britain in exiting the European Union. There is tension, too, over whether the backlash is really about a strain on Denmarkâ€™s generous public benefits or a rising terrorist threat  â€”   or whether a longstanding but latent racial hostility is being unearthed. Analysts say that the public voiced little opposition after 5, 000 Poles and 3, 300 Americans, among other Westerners, emigrated to Denmark in 2014, but that there has been significant criticism of the nearly 16, 000 Syrian asylum seekers who arrived that year and the next. They and other migrants were not invited, and many ended up here by accident, intercepted on their route to Sweden. Critics complain that these newcomers have been slow to learn Danish  â€”   though the Immigration Ministry recently reported that 72 percent passed a required language exam. Some Danes bristle at what they see as ethnic enclaves: About 30 percent of new immigrants lived in the nationâ€™s two largest cities, Aarhus and Copenhagen, where Muslim women in abayas and men in prayer caps stand out among the blond and   crowds on narrow streets. Perhaps the leading  â€”   and most substantive  â€”   concern is that the migrants are an economic drain. In 2014, 48 percent of immigrants from   countries ages 16 to 64 were employed, compared with 74 percent of native Danes. The Immigration Ministry has sought to avoid what it calls â€œparallel societiesâ€ of migrants living in â€œvicious circles of bad image, social problems and a high rate of unemployment. â€ Tightened immigration requirements, the ministry said in its latest annual report, weed out those â€œwho have weaker capabilities for being able to integrate into Danish society. â€ Omar Mahmoud, 34, an Iraqi engineer who entered Denmark a year ago and lives in a refugee center in Randers, a city of 60, 000, is trying his best to fit in. He and his wife are taking Danish classes, and their three children are learning the language and making Danish friends in school. They are Muslim, but attend church to learn about Christianity, and he said he was not opposed to his sonâ€™s eating pork, a staple of the Danish diet, though it is forbidden in Islam. Mr. Mahmoud said his family had not encountered direct insults or threats, but was frightened by the   and   tenor in the public discourse. â€œItâ€™s like foreigners are put in a special clan, separate from the Danish people,â€ he lamented. Still, Mr. Mahmoud said that â€œsome of the Danish people are angelsâ€ and that he was relieved to be far from the violence of Iraq. â€œIâ€™m in my heaven now. â€ Anders   a   city councilman in Randers, said the influx had forced a more honest conversation about national identity. â€œOur problem in Denmark is that weâ€™ve been too polite,â€ he said. â€œNo one dared talk aboutâ€ immigration, he added, â€œbecause they were afraid theyâ€™d be called racist. â€ Denmark is just one of many European nations grappling with the wave of migrants amid a spate of terrorist attacks across the Continent by Islamic extremists: A recent Pew Research Center survey found that at least half the citizens in eight of 10 countries polled said incoming refugees increased the likelihood of terrorist attacks. The confluence of these and other factors has prompted a   of the postwar promise of a unified, borderless Europe. Macedonia, Hungary and Slovenia have all built border fences. Denmark imposed new identity controls on its border with Germany in January, and for the first time since 1958, Sweden requires entering Danes to show identity papers. Many analysts saw Britainâ€™s surprise vote to leave the European Union as an angry expression of concern that British  â€”   or, especially, English  â€”   identity was being diluted by the nationâ€™s growing diversity. Debate is raging anew over whether certain Islamic modes of dress  â€”     swimsuits, known as burkinis, in France and face veils in Germany  â€”   inherently contravene countriesâ€™ values. Similar themes are seen as underpinning a wave of new measures here in Denmark. The government has made its citizenship test more difficult and slashed by nearly half a package of integration benefits. A measure passed in January, though rarely enforced, empowers the authorities to confiscate valuables from new arrivals to offset the cost of settling them. Last year, Denmark placed ads in   newspapers stressing its tough new policies, essentially suggesting: Donâ€™t come here. Muslims do not assimilate as easily as Europeans or some Asians, said Denmarkâ€™s culture minister, Bertel Haarder, partly because, as he put it, their patriarchal culture frowns on women working outside the home and often constrains freedom of speech. â€œItâ€™s not racism to be aware of the difference  â€”   itâ€™s stupid not to be aware,â€ Mr. Haarder said. â€œWe do them a blessing by being very clear and outspoken as to what kind of country they have come to, what are our basic values. â€ But much of the difference remains unspoken. This is a country where pedestrians wait for a green light to cross even when no cars are in sight, a contrast to the bustling streets of Middle Eastern capitals. Birgitte Romme Larsen, a Danish anthropologist who has studied refugees and asylum seekers in rural areas, mentioned an African refugee who did not realize that closing his curtains during the day was interpreted as being unduly secretive. Other newcomers were not aware that congregating and talking loudly at a grocery might offend Danish sensibilities. â€œThese implicit expectations cannot be written into an integration folderâ€ migrants receive, Ms. Larsen said. Sherif Sulaiman, an organic food scientist who moved to Denmark eight years ago from Egypt, said Muslims must not close themselves off in enclaves but open themselves up for interaction. He is the manager of an Islamic center that opened in 2014 and invites Danes in for meals and for an annual â€œharmony week. â€ Mr. Sulaiman pushed to have the mosque complex use Scandinavian architectural style and furniture, and lends its conference room to a church for meetings. â€œWe should be like this glass  â€”   transparent,â€ he said, pointing to a window. â€œAs long as we follow the rules of the country, we are part of Danish society. â€ But some   immigrants who have lived in Denmark for decades say assimilation seems an elusive and   target. Patricia Bandak and her brother Sylvester Bbaale came to Denmark from Uganda as babies in 1989. Like their native neighbors, they are polite and punctual and ride their bicycles everywhere. The siblings are not Muslim but said they frequently encountered racism: In school, they were called the N word, and told that they should stop eating Ugandan food like matoke, a starchy fruit. Mr. Bbaale, 27, who operates a food truck, said he was beaten on the street last year by three men who cursed at him and told him to go back to Africa. â€œFor a lot of people, being Danish is in your blood, so I will never be Danish,â€ said Ms. Bandak, 28, who became a Danish citizen in 2010 and is studying documentary film. â€œI call myself a Dane of a different color. â€ Then there is Ozlem Cekic, a   Muslim who served as a leftist member of Parliament from 2007 to 2015. Her three children were born in Denmark, she wrote a 2009 memoir in Danish, and, she said, â€œI even dream in Danish. â€ Yet Mrs. Cekic, 40, said she often received death threats and heard shouts of â€œGo home!â€ on the street. Every time terrorists strike Europe, she is bombarded by hundreds of hate messages. Lately, people have inundated her with accusations that Muslims are milking the welfare system and plotting against Danes. While in Parliament, Mrs. Cekic held â€œdialogue coffees,â€ at which she would explain  â€”   in fluent Danish  â€”   why she is as Danish as anyone. â€œThey meet me for coffee and suddenly they say their problem isnâ€™t with me but with those other people,â€ she recalled. â€œI tell them, â€˜I am the other. â€™â€ Karin Andersen is one of thousands of Danes trying to help the immigrants settle through groups formed on Facebook called Venligboerne, or Kind Citizens. She spends several days each month with Housam Mohammed Shamden, 38, his wife and two daughters, who fled Syria in 2014 and now live in Randers, with small Danish flags taped to the front door of their apartment and tucked into flower vases. â€œDanes are so concerned about losing their culture,â€ said Ms. Andersen, 62, a retired teacher. â€œBut how many help the ones who want to be part of it?â€ However many, they are often drowned out by reports of Muslims being spat at and showered with racist slurs. In May, two Danes ripped the head scarves off two girls. The month before, a national controversy erupted after a public swimming pool in Copenhagen created   lessons in response to Muslim requests. â€œFreedom of speech is now interpreted as freedom to say anything hateful,â€ said Julie Jeeg, a law student who volunteers with an antiracism group. â€œDenmark is closing in on itself. People are retreating inward. â€ Witness the â€œmeatball war. â€ In January, after revelations that a Randers day care center had stopped serving pork meatballs since its Muslim students would not eat them, the Town Council narrowly passed a measure requiring that pork be served â€œon equal terms with other kinds of food. â€ The councilman who pushed the measure, Frank Noergaard of the Danish Peopleâ€™s Party, said he was incensed that â€œpork could be abandoned in Denmark,â€ adding, â€œIf you give in on pork, whatâ€™s next?â€

title: Apparently, Donald Trump has already activated the â€˜reset buttonâ€™ with Russia
author: BareNakedIslam
text:
Apparently, Donald Trump has already activated the â€˜reset buttonâ€™ with Russia And this is why Hillary Clinton never could. Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed his bewilderment at why European countries were taking in so many migrants given the increasing number of rapes sweeping the continent, asserting that a society which cannot protect its children â€œhas no futureâ€. Putin made reference to a story out of Austria where an Iraqi migrant was not punished for raping a 10-year-old boy at a swimming pool in Vienna after he claimed it was a â€œsexual emergencyâ€ and that he didnâ€™t understand the boy didnâ€™t want to be raped. â€œI canâ€™t even explain the rationale â€“ is it a sense of guilt before the illegal alien Muslim migrants? A society that cannot defend its children today has no tomorrow, it has no future,â€ warned Putin, adding that he would not look to Europe for advice on Russiaâ€™s immigration policy given the situation that is unfolding there. 
h/t Rob E

title: The Playboy Mansion Has a Buyer: A Twinkie King - The New York Times
author: Jonah Engel Bromwich
text: The Playboy Mansion, the quintessential party house that held a special place in the imagination of American men for decades, has found a buyer, a Playboy spokesman said on Tuesday. The spokesman, John Vlautin, said the Los Angeles mansion, home to Hugh Hefner, 90, the founder of Playboy Magazine, was under contract to be sold to Daren Metropoulos, 32, a principal at the private equity firm Metropoulos  Company and an owner of Hostess Brands, the maker of that indestructible,   snack cake, the Twinkie. Mr. Vlautin declined to comment on the financial details, citing confidentiality restrictions. The house, which is nearly 20, 000 square feet, according to its sales listing, was built in 1927 in the Holmby Hills neighborhood of Los Angeles and has 29 rooms, including 12 bedrooms. It has a wine cellar, a theater, a gym, tennis courts and a huge swimming pool, complete with a shadowy grotto. Its listing price: $200 million. The listing also said the mansion was â€œone of a select few private residences in L. A. with a zoo license. â€ Mr. Metropoulos will not have to go far once the purchase is completed: He lives next door in a house he acquired in 2009. He would, however, have to be willing to live with a nonagenarian celebrity roommate if he wanted to move in right away. Mr. Vlautin said that, regardless of the sale, Mr. Hefner planned to stay in the house indefinitely. Playboy bought the house in 1971, and Mr. Hefner moved in (permanently) in 1975. A spokeswoman for Mr. Metropoulosâ€™s company said in a statement that after Mr. Hefnerâ€™s tenancy ends, the buyer hoped to connect his current house with the Playboy Mansion, â€œultimately returning the combined 7.  compound to the original vision executed by noted architect Arthur R. Kelly. â€ The mansion is famous for the lavish parties hosted by Mr. Hefner and attended by the rich, the famous and the  . The house has been featured as the ideal party destination for men in movies like â€œBeverly Hills Cop IIâ€ and television shows like â€œEntourageâ€ on HBO. Holly Madison, a former girlfriend and housemate of Mr. Hefnerâ€™s and one of the stars of the E! reality show â€œThe Girls Next Door,â€ which frequently featured the mansion, offered a different perspective on the house in her 2015 memoir. She called the climate â€œtoxicâ€ and described a stifling atmosphere that caused her to develop a stutter and even to consider suicide. Mr. Metropoulos told The Wall Street Journal, which reported the deal, that he was more interested in the mansionâ€™s historic architecture than its reputation as a party pad. â€œThe heritage of this property transcends its celebrity, and to have the opportunity to serve as its steward would be a true privilege,â€ he said. The Playboy Mansion was listed for sale early this year, and potential buyers expressed interest in acquiring Playboy Enterprises in its entirety. The company has suffered since the advent of internet pornography, and in March, its magazine stopped featuring fully nude women.

title: How Egyptâ€™s Activists Became â€˜Generation Jailâ€™ - The New York Times
author: Joshua Hammer
text: Every morning at 5:30, an alarm clock awakens Ahmed Maher from his mattress below a stairwell at his neighborhood police station in Cairo. An officer then escorts him to the toilet and signs a notebook that Maher carries, authorizing his release until 6 that evening. Maher walks a mile to his apartment  â€”   â€œIt is my only exercise,â€ he said  â€”   in the Third Settlement, a grid of   tenements at the edge of the desert. After breakfast with his wife and two small children, he takes care of chores aimed at rebuilding his life  â€”   renewing his driverâ€™s license, reactivating his cellphone he visits friends and family and searches for a job in civil engineering, his occupation before he was clapped into prison. Whatever he does, he must be back at the police station before sundown. â€œEvery second now is important,â€ said Maher, a slight    with a full beard, large eyes obscured behind tinted yellow lenses and a gray woolen ski cap that covered his bald pate. â€œIf I want to visit my mother in Maadi, I can spend three hours getting there and back. â€ The clock is ticking. â€œIf I delay for 15 minutes, the police have the right to send me back to prison,â€ he said. Maher and I were sitting in his small, dark apartment at 3 oâ€™clock on a Sunday afternoon in February, waiting for his children to return from their first day back at school after a   vacation. A television played a soccer match in a corner, and a coffee table was strewn with textbooks from Maherâ€™s studies at Cairo University, where he is pursuing a second degree, in political science, this one begun behind bars. It was just six years ago that Maher was celebrated around the world as a symbol of freedom and democracy. In January 2011, as the leader of a    network of young activists called the April 6 Youth Movement, Maher mobilized hundreds of thousands of Egyptians in demonstrations in Cairoâ€™s Tahrir Square and across the country that took down President Hosni Mubarak. The movement was considered for a Nobel Peace Prize, and Maher traveled across Europe and the United States talking about the Arab Spring and Egyptâ€™s future with the likes of Ban   and Lech Walesa. But the hopes that were raised by the revolution dissolved into sectarianism and chaos, and Maherâ€™s aspirations were extinguished within two years. Abdel Fattah   the defense minister and commander in chief of the armed forces, seized power in July 2013 and outlawed protests. Five months later, a judge found Maher guilty of illegal demonstration, rioting and â€œthuggeryâ€ and sentenced him to three years in jail. Another judge added six months to Maherâ€™s sentence for â€œverbally assaulting a public officer while on dutyâ€ after he demanded that the police remove his handcuffs while in court for a 2014 appeal. Maher spent almost all of that period sealed in a small cell in a   wing at Tora Prison, a notorious complex on the outskirts of Cairo, built during British rule, that houses about 2, 500 political prisoners and common criminals. Hidden behind    walls, the vast compound encompasses seven prison blocks, ranging from a   facility for policemen and judges convicted of taking bribes to the supermax â€œScorpion Prison,â€ a labyrinth of cells largely reserved for Islamists and April 6 leaders. Today Maher is nominally a free man, but the restrictions on his movements are stifling. The regime is deeply concerned that he could revive the   network that brought his followers to the streets six years ago. As it was explained to Maher, â€œtweets can lead to demonstrations, and demonstrations can lead to revolution, and that will bring down the regime and create martyrs,â€ he said. â€œSo if you are tweeting, you are like a terrorist. â€ Every day for the next three years, Maher must spend 12 of every 24 hours at his local police station, a â€œsurveillance periodâ€ intended to ensure that he refrains from   activity. Under Egyptian law, he told me,   felons â€œhave the right to have their surveillance inside the home with a guard downstairs. But they are using this surveillance as punishment. It is a kind of control to keep me all the time under pressure. â€ The front door opened, and Maherâ€™s wife, Reham, their daughter, Meral, 9, and their son, Nidal, 5, spilled into the room. Nidal raced to the television, switched it from the soccer match to a cartoon and then snuggled up to his father. â€œI missed these moments,â€ Maher said. During his incarceration, his contact with the children was limited to short visits twice a month. The encounters left his kids perplexed and disturbed. â€œAt first I lied when they would visit me,â€ Maher recalled. â€œMy daughter asked, â€˜Why you are not in our home?â€™ and I said, â€˜This is my job.â€™ She said, â€˜So why are you wearing blue? â€™â€™u2009â€ Reham, who met Maher at Cairo University 16 years ago and married him in 2007, told me that after a year they decided to explain the situation to their daughter. â€œI tried to make her grasp the difference between being detained for political reasons and being a common criminal,â€ Reham said. â€œI explained what the revolution was and how people protested. And I told her that when the current regime took over, it didnâ€™t allow people to express their opinions. Sisi knew what happened to Mubarak, so he didnâ€™t want them to speak out again. â€ In prison, Maher earned a reputation as a defiant figure, repeatedly sending antigovernment criticism and vivid descriptions of his ordeal to the Western and Egyptian news media. â€œWhen I heard the president talk about the rule of law and human rights in Egypt, I said, â€˜What is this bullshit? â€™â€™u2009â€ he told me. â€œThat made me want to write about the reality. â€ Denied pens and paper, he scribbled messages on tissues, using pens smuggled into his cell, and managed to smuggle the notes out. After they were published, guards would tear apart his cell, removing bricks from walls to search for hiding places. They confiscated his books, radio and clothes, leaving him with only his thin prison uniform. At one point, they covered the open exercise yard with a tarpaulin, blotting out the sunlight, suspecting that Maher might somehow be smuggling messages through the air. Still he continued devising acts of rebellion. A year into his confinement, Maher grew an extravagant handlebar mustache and a long beard and then braided it. â€œIt bothered them  â€”   it seemed like I was making fun,â€ he said. â€œThe prison officials complained to my father. They said, â€˜Please tell him to shave. â€™â€™u2009â€ After getting out of jail, Maher decided to keep wearing facial hair it helped disguise his identity. Maherâ€™s face is widely recognized in Egypt, and other April 6 Youth Movement leaders have been physically attacked by regime loyalists who blame them for plunging the country into instability and violence. When his wife enrolled their children in private school after Maher was sentenced to prison, she told the administrators that their father was â€œout of the country on business. â€ The school never connected their fatherâ€™s name to the famous activist, and even now, Maher said, when he picks his children up from their school, the staff has no idea who he is. Maher had to be careful with what he told me the regime might send him back to prison if he criticized Sisi too harshly. â€œEven if it was something minor, they would jail him,â€ Reham said. â€œIt would be a catastrophe for us. â€ Yet Maherâ€™s reluctance runs against all his instincts. Since his release, he has sensed a deepening anger toward the regime, and he believes that the political climate may be changing. â€œPeople tell me that they can see through the lies,â€ he said, â€œand that they are supporting us. â€ Sisiâ€™s crackdown on the opposition far exceeds the darkest period of repression during the Mubarak era. Human rights groups claim that as many as 60, 000 political prisoners now languish in Egyptâ€™s jails. (At the end of Mubarakâ€™s rule, the figure was between 5, 000 and 10, 000.) Egyptâ€™s prisons are filled to triple their capacity, and the regime has built 16 more prisons to handle the overflow. Once described by Amnesty International as â€œGeneration Protest,â€ the youths who took to the streets in Egypt to bring down a dictator in 2011 have acquired a grim new nickname: â€œGeneration Jail. â€ Many Egyptians have accepted Sisiâ€™s argument that another prolonged round of protests could invite radical Islamists to capitalize on the chaos. â€œHeâ€™s positioned himself as the sole leader who makes decisions because he knows whatâ€™s best for the nation, and heâ€™s saving us from the fate of Syria and Libya,â€ Khaled Dawoud, a prominent Egyptian journalist and the leader of a small opposition party, told me. Egyptians are proud that the first Arab leader to whom President Trump spoke after his electoral victory was Sisi, a sharp contrast to Barack Obama, who had suspended military aid to Egypt for two years after the police massacre of 1, 000 Muslim Brotherhood supporters in August 2013 at Rabaa, a Cairo encampment. Obama never invited the Egyptian president to the White House. â€œThe thinking is, Egypt is returning to its rightful place as a player,â€ said a veteran political observer in Cairo, who like many officials I spoke to feared retribution for discussing even   elements of Sisiâ€™s policies. Sisiâ€™s crackdown has unfolded amid one of the most expansive overhauls of the legal system in Egyptian history. After declaring a state of emergency and disbanding Parliament in 2013, he issued a series of presidential decrees that granted him unprecedented power to silence his critics. A protest law enacted in November 2013 requires three daysâ€™ notification before a demonstration can take place and gives the Interior Ministry the right to â€œcancel, postpone or moveâ€ the protest if it determines protesters will â€œbreach . .. the law. â€ Broad new counterterrorism laws have expanded the definition of terrorism to include civil disobedience this gives prosecutors latitude to roll over   pretrial detention periods, in many cases without limit. And once a case gets to court, a compliant judiciary, long regarded as hostile to the opposition, has been unforgiving in its sentencing. â€œThis is an extraordinarily conservative institution,â€ one official told me, explaining that judges tend to favor a â€œmaximalist approachâ€ to eliminate threats to the public order and safeguard their own interests. â€œThey are overwhelmingly the children of judges, like gondoliers in Venice. It is a family business. â€ According to the Arabic Network for Human Rights Information, a watchdog group in Cairo, the minister of justice has fired almost half of the 75 judges who called for more democracy in an open letter to Sisi and replaced them with  . Two hundred others have been sidelined with administrative chores or have left the country. One of the most notorious magistrates, Mohammed Nagy Shehata, known as the â€œexecutioner judge,â€ a holdover from the Mubarak era, has handed out hundreds of lengthy prison terms and death sentences to   activists. In early 2016, Shehata sentenced three young members of April 6, who were attending a memorial service for a murdered comrade when they were arrested, to life terms for protesting without a license, possessing fireworks and spreading false information. (The sentences were later reduced to 10 years.) In June 2014, another Cairo judge sentenced 25 peaceful demonstrators, some of them teenagers, to 15 years for violating the protest law, blocking roads and attacking public institutions. â€œKids are going to jail for four or five years,â€ Dawoud said, â€œbeing portrayed as anarchists and terrorists. No country in the world jails its young people for that long for demonstrating peacefully. â€ During the Mubarak era, he said, â€œI would take part in demonstrations and spend three days in a police station. We got released because we were students, and they were not going to destroy our future. There is no more of that kind of thinking. â€ Sameh Samir, a lawyer with the Egyptian Center for Economic and Social Rights, a nongovernmental organization that defends many protesters, told me that his office has been overwhelmed by the caseload. â€œThey are making random arrests, just sweeping people off the streets,â€ he said. The regime has hampered the ability of human rights groups like Samirâ€™s to defend protesters, freezing their bank accounts and making it increasingly difficult to accept foreign funds, often a lifeline for such organizations. Ten and a Half Kilometers Camp, a collection of concrete bungalows surrounded by a fence just off the    highway, typifies the prisons of the Sisi era. Built under Mubarak to house violent Islamists, the camp today serves as a pretrial detention facility for Islamists and a handful of secular political prisoners. A founding member of April 6 named Ayman, who did not want his last name mentioned, landed there in December 2015 after participating in an illegal protest. Thrown into a      cell with 35 Islamists, he slept amid a crush of other prisoners on a blanket on the concrete floor. They defecated in a hole surrounded by curtains and were never permitted to leave the cell. â€œYou need to take the word â€˜privacyâ€™ out of your dictionary if you are going to survive,â€ he told me. After two weeks, Ayman was moved into a tiny disciplinary cell with 11 other prisoners to await interrogation. They shared a few thin blankets, drank unpurified water from a rusty pipe and survived on one piece of stale bread and cheese each day. A fluorescent light in the   ceiling shone day and night. â€œWe learned how to get it unscrewed by standing on each otherâ€™s shoulders,â€ he said. â€œWe had to use a little acrobatics. â€ Twice during his 26 days in the unit, he was shaken awake in the night, blindfolded, taken to an interrogation room and questioned for hours. â€œThey asked me how the hierarchy of April 6 worked, how do we communicate,â€ he said. â€œI didnâ€™t give them any names. â€ The authorities finally moved him to Al Kanatar Prison, 15 miles from Cairo, where, after 20 days, a judge ordered his release. Ayman said that many of the prisoners he met were from the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist political organization that briefly held power after Mubarak. The group formally renounced violence in the early 1970s, but Ayman watched his cellmates grow hardened in prison. â€œThe torture and unjust imprisonment for long periods without clear charges or trial dates created human bombs,â€ he said. â€œEach one of them was just waiting to get out. They are so thirsty for revenge. â€ Last April, when he heard that the authorities were again looking for him, Ayman sought refuge in South Africa, where his wife and two young daughters eventually joined him. Egyptâ€™s slide back into authoritarianism wasnâ€™t foreordained. Today the leaders of April 6 admit that they werenâ€™t prepared for the challenges that followed their initial success. Many of them were barely out of their teens Maher, from a politically aware,   family in Cairo, had built the group online, connecting on Facebook and embracing   techniques that he learned while demonstrating for human rights and judicial independence with a small   movement. He was beaten and jailed repeatedly. The group took its name from the date of a   strike in Cairo that Maher organized in 2008 in solidarity with textile workers in the Nile Delta. That led to small demonstrations against corruption and police brutality, which were quickly broken up by Mubarakâ€™s security forces. Then, on Jan. 25, 2011, a protest march on Egyptâ€™s National Police Day exploded into a nationwide movement. Late that morning, Maher watched with amazement as crowds filled Tahrir Square and said: â€œWe made a revolution! We made a revolution!â€ Days after the Feb. 11 resignation of Mubarak, one of the worldâ€™s   tyrants, the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, a transitional military body, sent a bus to pick up Maher and three other protest leaders and took them to a villa owned by   officials. Sisi, then the intelligence chief, and two other generals greeted them respectfully, Maher recalled. â€œSisi said: â€˜You are heroes. You did miracles. You brought down Mubarak. You did something we failed to do for years. But now we need you to stop demonstrating. â€™â€™u2009â€ Maher and the others rejected Sisiâ€™s request. â€œWe said: â€˜The revolution is not complete. We need to change the cabinet, change the structure of the government.â€™ We kept sending them demands. â€ Over the next six months, Maher met with Sisi three times. â€œWe said the same, and he said the same. â€˜We need to stop demonstrating stand together against the enemies.â€™ Sisi always hated the protests. â€ After Mubarakâ€™s downfall, Maher traveled to the United States and captivated students in gatherings at New York University, Harvard, M. I. T. and American University, and met with leaders of the   community. In Europe, he talked politics and revolution with the first vice president of the European Commission, Catherine Ashton officials from the United Nations Human Rights Council and Green Party and Social Democratic representatives to the European Parliament in Brussels. Western diplomats and politicians underestimated the structural weakness of the secular democrats, the   appeal of the Islamists and the entrenched power of the â€œdeep stateâ€  â€”   military intelligence and the state security apparatus. Back in Egypt, the April 6 leaders searched for a strategy. â€œWe didnâ€™t have a vision,â€ admitted Walid Shawky, a dentist and a member of the April 6 Political Committee. â€œWe didnâ€™t have an answer for what comes next. â€ Maher struggled to articulate an ideology, vaguely describing the groupâ€™s leanings as â€œsocial democratic, social liberalâ€  â€”   somewhere between unfettered capitalism and   communism. There were debates between those who wanted to transform April 6 into a secular political party that would challenge the Muslim Brotherhood and those, like Maher, who believed that such a transformation was too ambitious. The Brotherhood â€œoutnumbered us 10 to one,â€ he told me. â€œI thought that being a pressure group to write a new Constitution would be a better role for us. â€ April 6 began an awareness campaign throughout the country. â€œWe used to go out with slide projectors in rural areas, teaching people of all the [human rights] violations made by the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces,â€ recalls Mamdouh Gamal, one of tens of thousands of youths who joined the movement in the immediate aftermath of the revolution. He has since left it. While April 6 members continued their activism, the Islamists cemented their political advantage. The Muslim Brotherhood won parliamentary and presidential elections but enraged much of the population when it tried to draft a Constitution based largely on fundamentalist Islamic principles. By the end of 2012, Egypt was in chaos. â€œThere were street fights, people at one anotherâ€™s throats, a real possibility of civil war,â€ remembered Dawoud, the journalist. April 6 gave its support to Tamarod, a   movement that gathered hundreds of thousands of signatures favoring early elections that, they believed, would remove the Muslim Brotherhood from power. Maher believed that they had the militaryâ€™s support. Instead, on July 3, 2013, Sisi went on television and announced that he was deposing President Mohammed Morsi and seizing power. He suspended the Constitution, disbanded Parliament, declared a state of emergency, ordered the arrests of Morsi and other Muslim Brotherhood leaders and then in August began the deadly attack on the Brotherhood protest camp at Rabaa. After nearly two years of turmoil, many Egyptians were desperate for stability, and April 6 suddenly found itself lacking any popular support. â€œAt that time, there was not one person in the street who was against Sisi,â€ recalled Amal Sharaf, the April 6 spokeswoman for the foreign media. After the killings, Sharaf said, â€œwe tried to make protests, and we got beaten. People with hammers and knives were chasing us.
