At the White House, Mr. Lee of Singapore responded to a question about Mr. Trump with diplomacy, and said Singapore would look forward to working with whomever Americans chose as president. â€œMany pressures build up during the election campaign, and after the elections in a calmer, cooler atmosphere, positions are rethought, strategies are nuanced, and a certain balance is kept in the direction of the ship of state. It does not turn completely upside down,â€ Mr. Lee said. â€œThe Americans take pride in having a system with checks and balances,â€ he added. â€œSo, it is not so easy to do things, but it is not so easy to completely mess things up. â€

title: Why Was A Mysterious Navy Plane Conducting â€œSecret Electronic Command/Control Drillâ€ Over Denver?
author: Mac Slavo
text:
Why Was A Mysterious Navy Plane Conducting â€œSecret Electronic Command/Control Drillâ€ Over Denver? Mac Slavo SHTFplan.com Read by 2 people 
It seems that the U.S. military is geared up for a permanent cyber war with the people and various governments of this globe. 
Though tensions with Russia may have been temporarily alleviated with the election of Donald Trump â€“ who has signaled for peace with Putin â€“ the long game is much more complicated. 
With new powers in Washington taking shape in the next administration, one faction in government was quietly, subtly parading its power. 
The Continuity of Government contingent of the shadow government will not be taken out of power by any mere election, and no matter what decisions Trump makes and no matter what inflammatory remark he may make, there are those who will still have their finger on the button. And that means a tremendous amount of power. 
Residents in the Denver area were presented with a mysterious white plane that flew in a â€œracetrack patternâ€ for more than an hour above the city before it landed at Tinker Air Force Base in Oklahoma, where the aircraft â€“ what the Navy has now disclosed to be an E-6B â€“ is housed. 
Hereâ€™s the bizarre route that observers tracked, and the Navy was later forced to confirm: â€œMysteriousâ€ plane circling over Denver was â€œjustâ€ an E-6B Mercury â€œdoomsdayâ€ plane https://t.co/SqJlBkdIqg pic.twitter.com/oE0BBWrhFL 
â€” The Aviationist (@TheAviationist) November 17, 2016 
Itâ€™s mission remains classified, but military officials admit a drill was underwayâ€¦ 
via ABC 7 Denver : 
A plane shrouded in mystery captured the attention of thousands on Wednesday. Nobody knew why a high-altitude plane circled the City of Denver for hours. Now the Navy has some answers. 
Denver7 tracked IRON99 as it traveled from the West Coast to Oklahoma, where it eventually landed at Tinker Air Force Base, however it spent roughly an hour in Denver, circling in a racetrack-style holding pattern over the city. 
Denver7 branded it a mystery in a previous report because officials from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), U.S. Northern Command (NORTHCOM), U.S. Strategic Command (STRATCOM), North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD) and a dozen Air Force Bases could not confirm what the flight may have been. 
A day later â€” after the plane landed â€” Navy officialsâ€¦ confirmed IRON99â€™s identity is a Navy E-6B Mercury, created by Boeing at a cost of $141.7 million per unit. 
The unitâ€™s overall mission is classified, Hubbell said, [elaborating that] the E-6B is â€œcommand, control and communications abilities to direct and employ strategic resources.â€ 
[â€¦] the planes are able to launch nuclear missiles and communicate with diverse assets, including nuclear submarines. 
[â€¦] a high-ranking federal official â€¦ said the plane was involved in a classified training mission organized by the Department of Defense. 
The training mission reportedly centered around electronic surveillance and involved several agencies which arenâ€™t likely to comment on the mission, the source said. 
Given that the E-6B deals with â€œcommand, control and communications,â€ as well as electronic surveillance and communications with nuclear submarines and other assets that could launch nuclear warâ€¦ one can assume that a major mission is in rehearsal â€“ to take charge of the nationâ€™s vital weapons and resources in the event of a catastrophic emergency, break down in order or disabling of the power structure in Washington. 
A similar E-4B was spotted flying above the capital on the morning of September 11th, shortly after the attacks. It was reportedly conducting a drill, but later instructed to prepare to go active as a mobile command center. Both planes deal with sensitive electronics communications involving, at least in part, nuclear launch codes and military continuity in the event of a breakdown of order. 
DOOMSDAY PLANES It is important to note that the E-4B is no ordinary aircraft. It is a militarized version of a Boeing 747-200, equipped with advanced communications equipment, and capable of carrying a crew of up to 112 people. Nicknamed â€œDoomsdayâ€ planes during the Cold War, E-4Bs serve the president, the secretary of defense, and the Joint Chiefs of Staff. In times of national emergency, they can act as highly-survivable command, control, and communications centers to direct forces, execute war orders, and coordinate actions by civil authorities. The U.S. military possesses four of them in total. One is always kept on alert, with a full battle staff. Offutt Air Force Base in Nebraska is the â€œMain Operating Baseâ€ for the E-4B, though there are also numerous â€œForward Operating Basesâ€ (FOB) throughout the U.S. [7] 
Hereâ€™s the reported layout of the E-6B, upgraded for the cutting edge of electronic warfare: 
In the current context, there are perhaps three distinct fronts that this command unit could have theater over. COMMUNICATIONS BLACKOUT â€“ The E-6Bâ€™s communications and control powers could be used to disrupt or disable electronic communications in the population over a given city or area. With sensitive military installations near Colorado Springs, the plane could have blacked out much of the Denver area accordingly with the situation. This CoG plane has dominance over the civilian population, and can bring their ordinary activities to a halt. Surveillance, data collection and â€˜drone detectionâ€™ may have also been objectives of this drill and real-life activities. CHECK AGAINST AGGRESSION â€“ The E-6Bâ€™s capabilities are a powerful counterbalance to possible hostile intentions on the part of Russia, China or other adversaries. As SHTF has often highlighted, modern warfare is based around the use of electromagnetic fields, communications jamming and, potentially, the use of an EMP to knock out electronics. Depending upon the potential situation, the ranking U.S. official on board or in communication with this plane could launch nuclear weapons, communicate with SSBN submarines around the globe or deny airspace to a conflicting force. TRUMP CARD FOR THE COG â€“ Symbolically, at least, the E-6B, conducting a drill a week or so after the election sends a message to the President-elect, and perhaps to his constituents as well, that there are limits to the power of a president. While Trumpâ€™s power is theoretically capped by the Constitutionâ€™s checks and balances, in the real world, the Continuity of Goverment (CoG) structure has operational superiority over any president, and perhaps they wanted to signal to Trump here (or perhaps not). If any president â€˜gets out of lineâ€™ or starts to â€˜believe they are truly in chargeâ€™, this plane can override their ego and maintain the dominance of the status quoâ€¦ it is a potential coup in motion. 
This is the true face of the ruling elite. This is the system they maintain, and anything below this threshold is not truly in charge. 
This what democracy looks like, when you strip away the silly game of voting, candidates and campaigns. 
This is the military industrial complex that Eisenhower warned us about. 
Read more:

title: Trump Busted For Flat Out Financially Scamming His Donors, Campaign Goes Into Last Minute Freefall
author: Jameson Parker
text:
Trumpâ€™s campaign has been frantic to close the huge gap in donations between Clintonâ€™s and their own. By some estimates, Hillary is outspending Trump 7-to-1 in advertising â€“ a steep hill to climb for a campaign that is already losing badly in nearly every battleground state. 
But in his desperation, Trump did something incredibly stupid. He promised his fans that he would â€œtriple matchâ€ any donation over $75 that they made on October 1st. 
His fans, believing Trump would put his money where his mouth is, gave generously. Instead of make good on the promise, Trump donated squat. In fact, his donations for the entire month were less than he should have donated that very first day. On Oct 1, I got an email from Trump pledging to triple donations for 24 hrs. 
Donors gave $165,829 that day. 
Trump gave $30,682 all month. 
â€” Ryan Struyk (@ryanstruyk) October 28, 2016 
Even for Trumpâ€™s diehard fans, this looks like the man is just the kind of grifter his critics have always claimed he was. Despite pretending to â€œself-fundâ€ his campaign, Trump has chipped in hardly anything. Heâ€™s run his campaign much like he ran his charity, using other peopleâ€™s money to promote himself. 
This is in stark contrast to Trumpâ€™s boasts. Famously, the candidate once said he was willing to spend upwards of one billion dollars on his campaign to be president. With just 11 days to go, Trump hasnâ€™t even come close. Most estimates put his own contribution around $50 million â€“ chump change for an alleged billionaire. Kellyanne Conway: The rest of Trumpâ€™s $100 million donation to his campaign is still coming (with 11 days left) pic.twitter.com/7U3UF9a0dM 
â€” Matthew Gertz (@MattGertz) October 28, 2016 
And it seems Trumpâ€™s campaign knows how badly he screwed this up. His campaign manager Kellyanne Conway scrambled to the nearest media outlet to proclaim that Trump would absolutely be fulfilling a promise he made to donate $100 million by the election. (Note again: He has just 11 days left to do so.) 
And then Trump himself reportedly wired $10 million to his campaign on Friday morning in a day late, dollar short desperation maneuver to help pull out of this tailspin. Donald Trump wired $10M of his own money into this presidential campaign this morning â€“ Dow Jones 
â€” CNBC Now (@CNBCnow) October 28, 2016 
Itâ€™s hard to truly be surprised that Trump has been stingy with his own campaign. This is the â€œbillionaireâ€ who managed to pay no taxes in twenty years and donate almost no money to charity in the same period. He makes Scrooge McDuck look generous. And with less than two weeks to go, Trumpâ€™s chances of becoming president are looking about as fictional as the cartoon duck. 
Go home, Donald. 
Featured image via Ethan Miller/Getty Images Share this Article!

title: Mexicans Say They Will Build Trump Wall â€“ Three Feet High
author: dailouk
text:
Home | World | Mexicans Say They Will Build Trump Wall â€“ Three Feet High Mexicans Say They Will Build Trump Wall â€“ Three Feet High By Eduardo Cojon 22/11/2016 11:46:05 
MEXICO CITY â€“ Mexico â€“ The Mexican government has agreed to Trumpâ€™s demands to build a wall along the U.S. border, and will start building as soon as Donald Trump is inaugurated as president in February 2017. 


Speaking from his presidential palace, Enrique PeÃ±a Nieto, revealed the Mexican plans to waiting journalists. 
â€œWe have taken up the mantle to build the wall and will foot the cost as well. As agreed, the wall will go along the entire U.S. Mexico border.â€ 
Unbeknownst to Trump, he did not specify how tall the wall should be, and when he finds out the wall will only be three feet high, he is sure to hit the roof. 
â€œThat is a minor detail we did not reveal to SeÃ±or Trump. The wall will be three feet high but it will fulfil our contract, and there is nothing the Don can do about it. Even an eight year old kid can jump over,â€ the Mexican president added. 
Trump was not available for immediate comment when contacted.

title: Trump vs. Congress: Now What? - The New York Times
author: Robert Draper
text: On Monday, Jan. 9, less than two weeks before President Trumpâ€™s inauguration, the House speaker, Paul Ryan, hosted a dinner at his office in the Capitol with members of Trumpâ€™s inner circle. The guests included the  â€™s chief White House strategist, Stephen K. Bannon his    and family consigliere, Jared Kushner his chief of staff, Reince Priebus his economic adviser, Gary Cohn his nominee for Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin his incoming deputy chief of staff, Rick Dearborn and his   director, Marc Short. The ostensible purpose of the dinner was to discuss the details of Trumpâ€™s legislative agenda  â€”   in particular, the prospects for a sweeping   measure that Republicans, and especially Ryan, have been coveting for the past decade. It was hoped that the dinner could also establish some sort of common ground between Ryan and Bannon, the two figures who would arguably wield the greatest influence over how Trumpâ€™s campaign promises became law  â€”   or didnâ€™t. Ryan was a fixture among establishment Republicans even before joining Mitt Romneyâ€™s presidential ticket in 2012, his previous labors on the House Budget Committee cementing his reputation as the    wizard of fiscal conservatism. Bannon, by contrast, was a renegade autodidact who read Plato and had seemingly materialized from nowhere to become the intellectual architect of Trumpâ€™s campaign and, later, administration. Up to this point, Ryan had epitomized to Bannon everything that was wrong with the Republican Party. Discussing the two partiesâ€™ shortcomings, Bannon later told me, â€œWhatâ€™s that Dostoyevsky line: Happy families are all the same, but unhappy families are unhappy in their own unique ways?â€ (He meant Tolstoy.) â€œI think the Democrats are fundamentally afflicted with the inability to discuss and have an adult conversation about economics and jobs, because theyâ€™re too consumed by identity politics. And then the Republicans, itâ€™s all this theoretical Cato Institute, Austrian economics, limited government  â€”   which just doesnâ€™t have any depth to it. Theyâ€™re not living in the real world. â€ Breitbart News, the   media outlet Bannon ran before becoming the chief executive of the Trump campaign in August, had described Ryan, referring to his position on immigration, as â€œarguably the most   G. O. P. lawmaker in Congressâ€  â€”   an apostasy of nearly impeachable proportions from Bannonâ€™s perspective. Worst of all, Ryan all but abandoned Trump during the 2016 campaign. After the leak in October of the damaging â€œAccess Hollywoodâ€ tape, Ryan told fellow Republican House members on a conference call, â€œI am not going to defend Donald Trump  â€”   not now, not in the future. â€ A Republican lawmaker on the call told Trump what Ryan had said, yet another reason for Bannon to regard himself as Ryanâ€™s worst enemy. But as the dinner progressed, it became clear that Bannon and Ryan actually had some ideas in common. Over memorably bad chicken Parmesan, Ryan described his vision for a â€œ  tax,â€ which would levy taxes on imports while offering exemptions for exports. His tax package would include â€œimmediate expensing,â€ he explained, in which capital expenditures would be written off against profits in the first year rather than over time. It also would abolish the alternative minimum tax and the estate tax. These were ideas Ryan had been pushing since 2008. Now they had Bannonâ€™s attention. Taken together with a drastic reduction in corporate taxes, Bannon believed, Ryanâ€™s scheme would spur a renaissance of a   export economy, producing   labor in keeping with Trumpâ€™s populism. â€œI would actually say,â€ Bannon remembers observing admiringly, â€œthat this tax reform comes as close to a first step of economic nationalism as there is. â€ â€œI would call it â€˜responsible nationalism,â€™â€™u2009â€ Ryan said, according to Bannon. Bannon laughed. â€œYouâ€™re going to have a lot of folks in the Senate say this is breathtakingly radical. â€ He meant it as a compliment. To Bannon, the entire world order  â€”   from the two political parties to the Wall Street reliance on leveraging to multiculturalism  â€”   was undergoing an extraordinary realignment, one made manifest in the 2016 election. According to Bannonâ€™s vision, economic nationalism would reorient priorities to the working classâ€™s benefit. Trade deals, jobs programs, tax incentives, immigration restrictions, environmental deregulation and even foreign policy would ultimately serve to restore the primacy of those Trump called â€œthe forgotten Americans. â€ In March, when I spoke to Trump by phone, I asked him what the term â€œeconomic nationalismâ€ meant to him. Compared with Bannonâ€™s revolutionary fervor, his reply was surprisingly cautious. â€œWell, â€˜nationalismâ€™  â€”   I define it as people who love the country and want it to do good,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t see â€˜nationalismâ€™ as a bad word. I see it as a very positive word. It doesnâ€™t mean we wonâ€™t trade with other countries. â€ Trumpâ€™s tone was genial but also a touch defensive. His postelection honeymoon had been short, if it existed at all. There were the administrative intrigues and   Twitter drama, along with the questions about his campaignâ€™s contacts with Russia, which had already forced the resignation of his national security adviser, Michael Flynn. Still, Trumpâ€™s legislative liaisons and their counterparts on Capitol Hill were doggedly negotiating a rollout of the Trump Era, one that would fulfill his most significant campaign promises  â€”   those that could not be done with just a stroke of Trumpâ€™s own pen but required acts of Congress. First, Obamacare would be repealed and replaced. Next, an austere budget would be passed, with emergency funds allotted for the construction of a wall along the Southern border. Then would come a   plan, presumably of the type Ryan and Bannon discussed. And finally, a bipartisan coalition would deliver a   infrastructure plan to Trumpâ€™s desk. If all this came to pass by the end of 2017, it would lend some credence to Trumpâ€™s pledge that this would be â€œthe busiest Congress weâ€™ve had in decades. â€ But by March, this timetable was looking like a formidable â€œif. â€ Trump himself seemed prone to distraction as he spoke to me from the Oval Office. Though I was asking about his policy aims, his musings swerved off to other vexations. More than once he denounced as â€œfake newsâ€ reports about his administrationâ€™s supposed disharmony. He brought up his speech before the joint session of Congress in February, â€œwhich I hope you liked, but I certainly have gotten great reviews  â€”   even the people who hate me gave me the highest review. â€ During the call, I could hear Priebus nearby, occasionally murmuring encouragement. Trump sounded more clipped and less jaunty on the call than he did during the discursive chats I had with him last year on the campaign trail. The business of governing had little to do with any trade he had previously practiced. In Congress, he was grappling with an arcane and famously inefficient ecosystem over which he had little if any control  â€”   and people he incessantly derided on the campaign trail as being â€œall talk and no action. â€ I asked him if he still felt that way. â€œItâ€™s like any other industry,â€ he replied, somewhat morosely. â€œIâ€™ve met some great politicians and some, to be honest, who arenâ€™t so hot. â€ Trump wanted to make sure that he was given adequate credit for his achievements, even in his administrationâ€™s infancy. â€œWeâ€™ve only been here for a tiny speck of time,â€ he said, â€œand what Iâ€™ve done with regulations, moving jobs back into the country, what Iâ€™ve done with airplane pricing and buying is amazing. Weâ€™ve done a lot. I think weâ€™ve done more than anybody for this short period of time. â€ Abraham Lincoln, Franklin Roosevelt and Lyndon Johnson would take exception to this claim. And Trumpâ€™s significant actions to date have consisted entirely of executive orders. What he has not yet demonstrated is his ability to actually shepherd a bill into law. The only major legislation that congressional committees have even seen thus far is a bill to repeal and replace Obamacare, which met with a stunning rebuke from Trumpâ€™s own party, forcing Ryan to withdraw the measure on the afternoon of March 24. At this stage of his presidency, Barack Obama had already signed into law his $787 billion   package and had moved on to holding White House meetings on health care. Itâ€™s conceivable that Trump could hit Day 100 with only minor symbolic legislative achievements to his name. For him to avoid this ignominy, the 45th president will have to develop a rapport with Washingtonâ€™s 535 federal deal makers, including the ones who â€œarenâ€™t so hot. â€ Whether Trumpâ€™s agenda succeeds will also depend in no small measure on the ability of Bannon to expand his game beyond 1600 Pennsylvania Ave. At 63, and with a fortune reported to be in the tens of millions of dollars  â€”   partly through his investment in the company that owns the syndication rights to â€œSeinfeldâ€  â€”   Bannon is regarded by Trump as a peer in the way that, say, the    lifelong politico Priebus is not. He is also approvingly seen as a fellow workaholic by the president (whose only known hobbies are golf and   CNN). And he is a deft operator who has learned from the successes and failures of other Trump advisers. He has carefully not claimed credit that the president would wish for himself and avoids giving expansive interviews on his own controversial views that might detract from his bossâ€™s celebrity. Like the former campaign manager Corey Lewandowski, Bannon understands that power in Trump World derives mainly from close and sustained physical proximity to the boss. Unlike Lewandowski, Bannon immediately grasped the importance of maintaining close relations with Jared Kushner, who factored heavily in Lewandowskiâ€™s dismissal from the Trump campaign last summer. But like Kushner, Bannon has never worked in government or at a   institute and has no meaningful experience when it comes to getting legislation passed. On the Hill, he has a few random associations  â€”   Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky and Representative John Culberson of Texas among them. Otherwise, he remains a looming but indistinct presence to the lawmakers who will be needed to pass most of Trumpâ€™s agenda. Bannonâ€™s interest in this agenda predated his association with Trump. One evening in January 2013, two guests showed up for dinner at the Capitol Hill townhouse that Bannon liked to call the Breitbart Embassy. One was the man Bannon would later describe to me as his â€œmentorâ€: Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama. The other was Sessionsâ€™s top aide and protÃ©gÃ©, a jittery    named Stephen Miller. Two months earlier, Obama decisively defeated Mitt Romney in the presidential election, prompting Priebus, then the chairman of the Republican National Committee, to commission an analysis of the state of the party and its future, known colloquially in Washington as the â€œautopsy,â€ which would be delivered that spring. The only certainty was that the report would urge Republicans to court the growing Latino electorate  â€”   which had voted for Obama by a   margin that November  â€”   by championing comprehensive immigration reform. The three men at the dinner table that night were among the few Republicans in town who thoroughly rejected that conclusion. Bannon wanted to talk to Sessions and Miller about a different report: an article written by Sean Trende, the senior elections analyst for the website RealClearPolitics, titled â€œThe Case of the Missing White Voters. â€ Trende observed that Obamaâ€™s victory was less a function of increased minority turnout than of the fact that 6. 6 million white voters who participated in the 2008 election stayed home in 2012. The reason for this drop, Trende argued, was that white   voters who did not approve of Obama but were alienated by Romneyâ€™s perceived elitism had not voted. These votes were gettable, Bannon believed. As he would later tell me: â€œThe working class, and in particular the lower middle class, understands something thatâ€™s so obvious  â€”   which is that theyâ€™ve basically underwritten the rise of China. Their jobs, their raises, their retirement accounts have all fueled the private equity and venture capital that built China. Because Chinaâ€™s really built on investments and exports, right? People are smart enough to know that theyâ€™re getting played by both political parties. The two may be different on social issues, but when it comes to fundamental economics, theyâ€™re both the same. Thatâ€™s why the American working class is interested in trade. Itâ€™s linked to their lives. â€ Sessions shared Bannonâ€™s belief that the Republican Party needed to emphasize immigration reduction, border security and the preservation of   jobs through trade policy rather than courting Latino voters with a bill he regarded as â€œamnesty. â€ As Sessions would write in a memorandum to his Republican colleagues six months later, â€œThis humble and honest populism  â€”   in contrast to the administrationâ€™s cheap demagoguery  â€”   would open the ears of millions who have turned away from our party. â€ At some point during the   dinner, Bannon recalls blurting out to Sessions, â€œWe have to run you for president. â€ Just two years earlier, in 2011, he made a similar pitch to Sarah Palin, after completing a documentary about her called â€œThe Undefeated. â€ Palin demurred. She was enjoying her life of celebrity and wealth, she had done little to immerse herself in policy minutiae and she was no doubt unsettled by Bannonâ€™s warning that she stood little chance of defeating Obama. Now he delivered a similar message to Sessions. â€œLook, youâ€™re not going to win,â€ he recalls saying. â€œBut you can get the Republican nomination. And once you control the apparatus, you can make fundamental changes. Trade is No. 100 on the partyâ€™s list. You can make it No. 1. Immigration is No. 10. We can make it No. 2. â€ Acknowledging that the drawling Alabama senator lacked Palinâ€™s charisma, Bannon said, â€œYouâ€™ll be the  . â€ But Sessions told Bannon he did not see himself running for president. â€œIt was pretty obvious by the end of the night,â€ Bannon recalled, â€œthat another candidate would have to do it. â€ Two months later, on March 15, 2013, Bannon happened to be attending the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington when Trump took the stage. Trump had been a marginal figure at most in politics up to that point, entertaining a Reform Party run in the 2000 election  â€”   when he speculated that he would probably take more votes from the Democratic candidate than the Republican one  â€”   and leading a conspiratorial crusade in 2011 to force Obama to release his birth certificate. The possibility that he might be a suitable host body for Bannonâ€™s worldview had not occurred to Bannon before Trump spoke. But Trumpâ€™s grousing references to Chinaâ€™s economic superiority, to 11 million â€œillegalsâ€ and to the erosion of Americaâ€™s manufacturing sector were right out of Bannonâ€™s playbook. From his desk in the Russell Senate Office Building, Stephen Miller, too, watched Trumpâ€™s speech. By 2014, Miller was sending emails to friends expressing the hope that Trump would run for president. By the time Trump announced his candidacy, in June 2015, Sessions was officially uncommitted but privately of the view that Trump was best suited to tap into the movement that he, Miller and Bannon discussed over dinner more than two years earlier. Bannonâ€™s early support for Trump was manifest in Breitbartâ€™s breathless coverage of his candidacy. In an email he sent on Aug. 30, 2015, to his former filmmaking partner Julia Jones, Bannon explained that while Republican candidates like Ted Cruz, Bobby Jindal, Ben Carson and Carly Fiorina were â€œall great,â€ Trump represented a superior choice, because he â€œis a nationalist who embraces Senator Sessionsâ€™s planâ€ on immigration. Still, recalls Sam Nunberg, Trumpâ€™s first campaign strategist, â€œSteve kept all of his cards. â€ He added: â€œHe was respectful to some of the other ones who were running, like Walker and Cruz and Carson. He didnâ€™t want to be seen as  . â€ When Trump publicly disparaged John McCainâ€™s   credentials, Bannon  â€”   himself a Navy veteran  â€”   called Nunberg and demanded that Trump issue an apology. (Trump did not.) Bannon was well positioned as a supportive but not sycophantic observer by Aug. 13, 2016, when the Trump donor Rebekah Mercer read with alarm a New York Times account of the Trump campaignâ€™s inability to handle its mercurial candidate. At Mercerâ€™s behest, Bannon (whose website Mercerâ€™s family helped underwrite) and Kellyanne Conway (who at that point was receiving money from both a Mercer family political action committee and the Trump campaign) flew out that day to East Hampton, N. Y. where Trump was attending a dinner   at the home of the New York Jetsâ€™ owner, Woody Johnson. After the dinner, Bannon and Conway huddled with the candidate. Bannon remembers telling Trump, who at the time was trailing Hillary Clinton by double digits in the polls, â€œAs long as you stick to the messageâ€  â€”   by which he meant economic nationalism  â€”   â€œyou have a 100 percent probability of winning. â€ A week after the election, in an interview with the journalist Michael Wolff, Bannon offered a bold, sweeping sketch of what the vision might mean in policy terms: â€œLike [Andrew] Jacksonâ€™s populism, weâ€™re going to build an entirely new political movement. Itâ€™s everything related to jobs. The conservatives are going to go crazy. â€ Of course, some of the conservatives Bannon intended to drive crazy possessed the congressional votes Bannon and Trump would need to advance this agenda. Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio, a leading conservative in the House, told me in March, â€œI would argue that populism, as long as itâ€™s rooted in conservative principle, is a darn good thing. â€ Jordan was smiling as he said it, but the note of warning was hard to mistake. The last time the Republican Party controlled all branches of government in Washington was from 2003 to 2007. During that period, the United States military toppled Saddam Hussein, Congress delivered tax cuts for the wealthy and President George W. Bush appointed the reliably conservative jurist Samuel A. Alito Jr. to the Supreme Court. But in the collective view of conservatives, these years of the Bush presidency were mostly characterized by betrayal and disappointment. Goaded by Bush, congressional Republicans passed into law a new federal entitlement (prescription drugs for senior citizens, also known as Medicare Part D) ran up the deficit, promoted democratic ideals overseas in the feckless manner of Woodrow Wilson, considered a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants and confirmed a Supreme Court chief justice, John G. Roberts Jr. whose swing vote would later save Obamacare from judicial evisceration. â€œMy   line when I first ran in 2008 was, â€˜Republicans had the House, the Senate and the White House  â€”   and they blew it,â€™â€™u2009â€ Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah, the chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, told me. â€œNow weâ€™ve got all three again, and Iâ€™m the guy whoâ€™s in Congress, not running for it. I donâ€™t want to be in a position where weâ€™re going to blow it one more time. â€ Chaffetz and other House conservatives freely acknowledge that Trump is not cut from their cloth, but they say they could not care less as long as he gives them what they want. Selecting Judge Neil Gorsuch to fill the Supreme Court seat once held by Justice Antonin Scalia was â€œthe best thing the president did in his first 50 days,â€ Chaffetz told me. He and his conservative colleagues have been cheered by Trumpâ€™s recruitment of former House colleagues and conservative stalwarts like Vice President Mike Pence Tom Price, the health and human services secretary and Mick Mulvaney, the Office of Management and Budget director. When Chaffetz and I spoke in March, he had met with the president twice so far  â€”   access he considered â€œsuch a huge sea changeâ€ from the stony silence Republicans say they encountered from the Obama White House. Most important, the Trump agendaâ€™s first three projected legislative moves  â€”   the Obamacare repeal and replacement, an austere budget and tax reform  â€”   were intended to keep conservatives happily in Trumpâ€™s camp. In turn, when the agenda moved on to less conservative items like infrastructure and trade agreements, Trump and Bannon would fully expect Republicans, including Ryan, to remember whose message resonated most with   voters last year. Representative Kevin McCarthy, the House majority leader, is Trumpâ€™s chief point of contact on the Hill. When McCarthy was a college student and budding entrepreneur in Bakersfield, Calif. in the late 1980s, his girlfriend at the time, now his wife, Judy, gave him an autographed copy of Trumpâ€™s â€œThe Art of the Deal. â€ â€œI thought it was great,â€ he told me. In McCarthyâ€™s view, Trump is a master of todayâ€™s media, much as Lincoln and Kennedy were in their own times. â€œHeâ€™s mastered instantaneous Twitter,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s like owning newspapers. â€ Trump has found a kindred spirit in McCarthy, a coastal extrovert of ambiguous ideological portfolio who (unlike Ryan) would far rather talk about personalities than the tax code. And as the former minority leader in the California Legislature during the governorship of Arnold Schwarzenegger, McCarthy is experienced in the care and feeding of celebrity egos. Since Trumpâ€™s nomination, the two have spoken frequently by phone  â€”   to date, Trump has never been known to directly email or text anyone  â€”   about the cast of 535 characters with whom the president must now deal. But in the end, what Trump needs from the majority leader is not gossip but votes  â€”   216 of them, to be exact, in the House. And McCarthyâ€™s recent track record in obtaining majorities has not been the greatest. In his previous capacity as House whip, he was thwarted by members of his own party when it came to subjects as diverse as reauthorizing a Patriot Act they deemed too intrusive, a farm bill they considered too expensive and a   bill they regarded as too lenient. His most reliable obstacles have been the three dozen or so House conservatives known as the Freedom Caucus, a    group of fiscal  . Early this year, McCarthy predicted to me that the new president would quickly subjugate the Freedom Caucus. â€œTrump is strong in their districts,â€ McCarthy told me. â€œThereâ€™s not a place for them to survive in this world. â€ When we spoke on the morning of March 7, Trump assured me that he would not bully the   billâ€™s loudest Republican critics, like the Freedom Caucus chairman, Representative Mark Meadows, on Twitter: â€œNo, I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll have to,â€ he said. â€œMark Meadows is a great guy and a friend of mine. I donâ€™t think heâ€™d ever disappoint me, or the party. I think heâ€™s great. No, I would never call him out on Twitter. Some of the others, too. I donâ€™t think weâ€™ll need to. Now, theyâ€™re fighting for their turf, but I donâ€™t think theyâ€™re going to be obstructionists. I spoke to Mark. Heâ€™s got some ideas. I think theyâ€™re very positive. â€ But on March 21, in a meeting with the Freedom Caucus about the bill, Trump called out Meadows by name, saying, â€œIâ€™m going to come after you, but I know I wonâ€™t have to, because I know youâ€™ll vote â€˜yes. â€™â€™u2009â€ Meadows remained a â€œnoâ€ on the bill, and among conservatives, he was far from alone. One of the Freedom Caucusâ€™s most outspoken members, Representative RaÃºl Labrador of Idaho, believes that the Trump White House was led astray by Ryanâ€™s confidence that he knew what conservatives wanted when drafting the bill. â€œThe legislation has to go through the body, not the top,â€ Labrador told me. â€œAnd if our leadership thinks now that weâ€™re a unified body, that they can do things while ignoring us, thatâ€™s not going to happen. â€ Labrador is an affable but decidedly stubborn    Mormon and former immigration lawyer who moved as a child with his single mother from Puerto Rico to Las Vegas. He was interviewed by the   for the post of interior secretary at Trump Tower last December  â€”   though Trump selected Labradorâ€™s House colleague Ryan Zinke for the post a few days later. For now, Labrador and other Freedom Caucus members have been willing to blame House leaders like Ryan and McCarthy for drafting a health care bill that was not to conservativesâ€™ liking. They aspire to remain philosophical whenever Trumpâ€™s daughter Ivanka persuades her father to propose initiatives like paid family leave, as he did during his   speech. â€œI didnâ€™t stand up when he said that,â€ Labrador said. â€œThatâ€™s the only part of the speech where I thought, Thatâ€™s not even close to what my party stands for. â€ To House conservatives like Labrador, the Republican Party stands for limited government. To Trump and Bannon,   items like a border wall and infrastructure take priority over shrinking Americaâ€™s debt. As Chaffetz admitted to me, â€œOn the spending front, things could slip away really quickly. â€ Trumpâ€™s budget blueprint is regarded by deficit hawks as fundamentally unserious, because it does not touch entitlements. Instead, it ravages perennial (and already  ) conservative piÃ±atas like foreign aid, public broadcasting and the National Endowment for the Arts, in addition to downsizing the Environmental Protection Agency and the Interior Department  â€”   cuts that focus on the 27 percent of the federal budget that is not mandatory spending or devoted to defense. And for all the Republicansâ€™ chesty rhetoric on cuts like these over the years, as a top House Republican staff member told me, â€œeven the cabinet secretaries at the E. P. A. and Interior are saying these cuts arenâ€™t going to happen. Theyâ€™re going to protect their grant programs, their payments to states, their Superfunds. So how do you cut 31 percent of the E. P. A. out of the 5 percent that isnâ€™t protected? And a bill that cuts all money for the N. E. A. will not pass. For Republicans in the Westâ€  â€”   states whose vast rural areas benefit disproportionately from N. E. A. grants  â€”   â€œthatâ€™s a   killer. The campaign commercials write themselves. â€ Labrador says he would defend Trumpâ€™s cuts but doubts that many of his colleagues would. â€œWhat heâ€™s going to learn is that members of Congress are unwilling to take the tough votes,â€ he told me. â€œWhen he learns that, whatâ€™s going to be the next step?â€ In Labradorâ€™s view, Trumpâ€™s only sane recourse will be to accept the need for entitlement reform. â€œAt some point, the reality of the budget is going to have to hit him,â€ he said. â€œYou can have this economic nationalism  â€”   Bannon is very smart, he clearly helped him with his messaging, it was so successful  â€”   but at some point, that theory is going to hit reality. â€ When I spoke with Trump, I ventured that, based on available evidence, it seemed as though conservatives probably shouldnâ€™t hold their breath for the next four years expecting entitlement reform. Trumpâ€™s reply was immediate. â€œI think youâ€™re right,â€ he said. In fact, Trump seemed much less animated by the subject of budget cuts than the subject of spending increases. â€œWeâ€™re also going to prime the pump,â€ he said. â€œYou know what I mean by â€˜prime the pumpâ€™? In order to get thisâ€  â€”   the economy  â€”   â€œgoing, and going big league, and having the jobs coming in and the taxes that will be cut very substantially and the regulations thatâ€™ll be going, weâ€™re going to have to prime the pump to some extent. In other words: Spend money to make a lot more money in the future. And thatâ€™ll happen. â€ A clearer elucidation of Keynesian liberalism could not have been delivered by Obama. The one clear point of agreement between the Trump economic nationalists and the House conservatives is the one Ryan and Bannon identified over dinner in January: tax reform. But in so doing, they will be picking a fight that may prove perilous to Republicans. The    proposal that Ryan floated to Bannon has never been able to get past K Street lobbyists and wealthy Republican donors like the Koch brothers. When I asked Trump if he was a fan of the   tax, he replied: â€œI am. Iâ€™m the king of that. â€ Almost no other country grafts an import tax onto a corporate tax, and itâ€™s possible that enacting a   tax might well be in violation of the World Trade Organizationâ€™s agreements. Of course, Bannon has openly advocated abandoning the W. T. O. anyway, because of Chinaâ€™s membership in it. Still, the specter of new taxes on American corporations, higher prices for consumers and a jump in the dollarâ€™s value may compel an unusual confederacy against the   plan. Labrador predicts that the   tax â€œwill have very little political legsâ€ in the conservative House, while Senator Lindsey Graham said in February that even in the   Senate, Ryanâ€™s tax plan â€œwonâ€™t get 10 votes. â€ Senator Heidi Heitkamp, a North Dakota Democrat who has been outspoken in her willingness to work with Trump in spite of the broader stance of her party, says, â€œLet me tell you, I represent farmers, and anyone who tells me that farm country benefits from a high dollar needs to have a discussion with me. â€ Perhaps the Republican faction most alarmed by Bannonâ€™s economic nationalism is Washingtonâ€™s military hawks. John McCain is among those not mollified by Trumpâ€™s pledge of enacting â€œone of the largest increases in   spending in American history. â€ McCain scoffed when I brought this up to him. â€œOf course thatâ€™s simply not true,â€ he said. â€œWhen you look at 1981 and Reaganâ€™s commitment to rebuilding the military, thereâ€™s no comparison to this 3 percent increase. Itâ€™s a shell game, my friend. â€ Despite his obvious differences with Trump, McCain was willing to work with him  â€”   but Bannonâ€™s presence seemed to confound such prospects. â€œItâ€™s kind of interesting,â€ McCain said, â€œbecause I have decades of experience with Kelly, with Mattis, with Dan Coats, McMaster,â€ referring to Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly Defense Secretary James Mattis Dan Coats, the director of national intelligence and H. R. McMaster, the national security adviser. â€œWe discuss issues all the time. I think this is probably the finest   team that Iâ€™ve ever observed. Itâ€™s almost schizophrenic, in that I obviously donâ€™t have conversations with Steve Bannon, but I do with Reince Priebus  â€”   he was my Republican chair in Wisconsin in my 2008 presidential campaign. So itâ€™s almost a schizophrenic  â€”   thatâ€™s not the right word. A very divided kind of relationship. Paradoxical. â€ McCain acknowledged to me that economic nationalism was a global movement and therefore not entirely â€œthe making of some members of the Trump entourage. â€ He then said: â€œBut it is an articulation that I believe is strongly reminiscent of the 1930s. It certainly has unsettled our allies and friends around the world, thereâ€™s no doubt about that. â€ Already, the senator asserted, the new administrationâ€™s bellicosity toward Mexico has increased the likelihood that its citizens will elect â€œa very     president. â€ As for an import tax of the sort favored by Bannon and Ryan, â€œtalk about harkening back to the 1930s,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s unbelievable to me that they somehow think if we start taxing goods coming across the border, that thatâ€™s somehow not going to be responded to by the Mexicans. Please. History shows this sort of action gets you into a trade war. â€ Listening to McCainâ€™s tirade, I found it evident that the Bannon Effect might well cost the Trump White House at least one Republican Senate vote on a number of central issues  â€”   this at a time when Republicans are clinging to a slender majority in the upper chamber. In such cases, Trump could find himself asking for something Obama was never able to count on: votes from the opposition. Early in the afternoon of Feb. 9, several Democratic senators met with Trump in the Roosevelt Room of the White House to discuss the Gorsuch nomination and other matters. Among them were Heidi Heitkamp, Joe Donnelly of Indiana, Joe Manchin of West Virginia and Jon Tester of Montana. All four are moderates who are up for   in 2018 in states Trump carried in 2016 by titanic margins  â€”   the least of which, in Donnellyâ€™s state, was nearly 20 points. If Democrats are to nurture any hopes of retaking the Senate majority, they will need to hold these four seats. But if Donnelly, Heitkamp, Manchin and Tester need to be seen back home as willing to work with Trump, the president needs them as well. Republicans enjoy a precarious    advantage in the Senate. On matters like the Supreme Court, Trump can count on all 52. On votes requiring a simple majority, any two of those Republicans could fall away, and Pence could preserve the win with a tiebreaking vote. But a trio of fiscal   (like Ted Cruz, Rand Paul and Mike Lee) military hawks (John McCain, Lindsey Graham and Marco Rubio) or social moderates (Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowski and Shelley Moore Capito) could deny Trump a majority, unless he could swing at least one Democrat to his side. That February afternoon in the Roosevelt Room, Donnelly thanked Trump for negotiating with Carrier, the manufacturing company based in Indiana that had threatened to move jobs to Mexico before Trump   it into keeping many of them in Indiana. But Donnelly urged him not to view that episode as a â€œ . â€ He requested the presidentâ€™s support for his End Outsourcing Act, which would give preferential treatment in awarding federal contracts to businesses that kept jobs in America. The words were scarcely out of Donnellyâ€™s mouth before Trump said, â€œIâ€™m 100 percent for that, and Iâ€™ll do everything I can to help get it passed. â€ He then asked Pence, who was in the room, â€œWhat do you think, Mike?â€ Trump was apparently unaware that Pence, as the governor of Donnellyâ€™s state, had refused to back the senatorâ€™s initiative, claiming instead that burdensome federal regulations were to blame for outsourcing. According to Donnelly, Pence gamely replied, â€œIf itâ€™s like what Joe describes, Iâ€™ll do everything I can to help. â€ Donnelly, a   Irish Catholic with a barroom guffaw, had met Trump once before. In January 2011, he was among the   Blue Dog Coalition, composed of conservative House Democrats  â€”   what remained of them, anyway, after the previous Novemberâ€™s disastrous midterms  â€”   who traveled to New York for their annual retreat. At a hotel conference room in Midtown Manhattan, the 20 or so Blue Dogs received a procession of guests, including Mayor Michael Bloomberg and former President Bill Clinton. Only one of their scheduled appointments required that they go to their guest  â€”   and so they did, by bus, to Trump Tower. Trump greeted them in his boardroom, with its commanding view of Central Park. He was charming but also brash. â€œRemember, at that point he wasnâ€™t really talking about running for office,â€ recalls one attendee, former Representative Dan Boren of Oklahoma. â€œBut what strikes me was how he talked about the same issues  â€”   the wall, China  â€”   that became his stump speech years later. â€ It was evident to the Blue Dogs that Trump was no Clinton or Bloomberg when it came to the issues. Says former Representative Ben Chandler of Kentucky, who was also in attendance: â€œThe difference in terms of detailed knowledge of policy was stark. Trump just made bald assertions, really. â€ Particularly memorable to Chandler was Trumpâ€™s insistence â€œthat one of the best things the country could do was slap a massive tariff on the Chinese. â€ Chandler continued: â€œHe seemed not to understand that this would probably cause the entire world economy to melt down by causing a huge trade war. What I remember more than anything else was our general reaction afterward. And it was one of disbelief. â€ Today Donnelly remains offended by what he calls Trumpâ€™s â€œcrazy stuff,â€ as well as the alternative to Obamacare that Trump supported. But he does not begrudge Trump his showmanship. â€œHe came to the Carrier plant,â€ Donnelly said. â€œIâ€™ve been working on that issue since Day 1. I was begging people in the Obama administration to come out and talk to our workers. Donald Trump came out there. And Donald Trump talked to our workers. You can tell people you care. But it matters if you show up. â€ The Senate Democrat who, to outward appearances, seems closest to Trump is Joe Manchin, who met face to face with the   in Trump Tower in December. Before the meeting, Bannon took the West Virginia senator aside. â€œThe thing you need to know about Trump,â€ Bannon said, â€œis he doesnâ€™t care about the Republican Party and he doesnâ€™t care about the Democratic Party. He just wants to put some wins on the board for the country. â€ In the meeting, Trump asked Manchin what could be done for coal miners. Manchin replied that he should support his Miners Protection Act, which would secure health benefits and pension funds for retired miners. According to Manchin, Trump replied that he would thoroughly support such a measure. Later that month, Manchin went on â€œMorning Joeâ€  â€”   the one show on MSNBC that Trump has been known to watch  â€”   to discuss, on the occasion of the fourth anniversary of the Newtown school massacre, the need to expand background checks on gun purchases. Within an hour after Manchin was offscreen, his cellphone rang. It was Trump. Manchin was not completely forthcoming about the conversation, but he did tell me that he envisioned â€œa complete opportunityâ€ for new   legislation. Unlike with Obama, he said, â€œno one thinks President Trump would do anything that would take away your gun rights. â€ In his conversations with Manchin and Donnelly, Trump was essentially throwing his support behind a Democratic initiative without first checking with the Republican Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, to ask what he thought of those proposals. Had he done so, the answer in each case would have been: not much. (Though on the coal minersâ€™ legislation, Manchin said: â€œWeâ€™re seeing Mitch McConnell go from a â€˜No, no and hell noâ€™ to now dropping his own bill. Which is fine, so long as we get it. â€) Still, Trump may have little choice but to indulge Democrats on some of their pet issues, given that he will need their votes on two of the most critical pieces of his agenda: infrastructure and trade deals. Until now, Trump has divulged few details about this   infrastructure venture. On the campaign trail, he frequently cited Americaâ€™s crumbling roads and bridges. He bemoaned the potholes defiling the runways at La Guardia Airport, where he parked his two planes. During Donnellyâ€™s visit with Trump in the Roosevelt Room, the president â€œtalked about the   Tunnel with the tiles falling off, which he would see on his way to La Guardia,â€ Donnelly recalled. (The Metropolitan Transportation Authority denies that tiles are falling off the tunnel.) When I asked Trump for more specifics, he gingerly offered a few morsels: â€œThis is something thatâ€™s going to be a real infrastructure bill, where real work is going to be done on bridges and roads and airports and things that weâ€™re supposed to be doing. So itâ€™s not just a political piece of paper. Weâ€™re going to do infrastructure, and itâ€™s going to be a very big thing. â€ Trumpâ€™s description struck me as uncharacteristically modest. Bannon had evoked a more gleaming vision when he told me: â€œLook, economic nationalism is predicated on a     infrastructure for the country, right? Broadband as good as Korea. Airports as good as China. Roads as good as Germany. A rail system as good as France. If youâ€™re going to be a   power, youâ€™ve got to have a   infrastructure. â€ When I asked the president if his initiative might include such features, he replied: â€œYes. It could, it could. You look at Japan and China, where they have the fast trains, and we donâ€™t have any. You look at other countries where we used to be the leader, and now weâ€™re the laggard. Itâ€™s not going to happen anymore. â€ What also may not happen is House Republicansâ€™ supporting a   bill that is at least somewhat reminiscent of the stimulus bill they unanimously opposed eight years ago. Itâ€™s also possible that even moderate Democrats in swing states may face pressure not to come to Trumpâ€™s rescue. After all, the president remains intensely unpopular among Democrats, who continue to nurture hopes that Trump is one Russia connection away from impeachment. As a senior White House official told me of Gorsuchâ€™s nomination to the Supreme Court: â€œThe comment we often get from Democrats is, â€˜Thatâ€™s a great nominee.â€™ Oh, so youâ€™re voting for him? â€˜I canâ€™t.â€™ Why not? â€˜My base would go crazy, and Iâ€™d be primaried.â€™ That environment has to change before we can have any of these conversations. â€ On the morning of Feb. 2, two Democratic leaders on trade issues, Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon and Representative Richard Neal of Massachusetts  â€”   the ranking members of the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means Committees  â€”   met with Trump, along with a few of his advisers and Republican lawmakers. Trump had already greeted the day by threatening to yank federal funding from the University of California at Berkeley after acts of violence had forced the cancellation of the Breitbart editor Milo Yiannopoulosâ€™s speech on campus, and by taunting Arnold Schwarzeneggerâ€™s poor ratings on â€œThe Apprenticeâ€ during the National Prayer Breakfast. Disquiet lingered from Trumpâ€™s travel ban on refugees and his surly phone conversation with the Australian prime minister the previous week. Amid this chaos  â€”   entirely to Bannonâ€™s liking and grating to nearly everyone else in Washington  â€”   actual legislative activity was slowly unfolding. Trump began the meeting by condemning the trade deals negotiated by his predecessors. The press pool was then ushered out before the Democrats could say anything in front of the cameras. When Neal was given a chance to speak, he informed Trump, Pence, Bannon, Kushner and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross that America had in fact prospered as a result of past trade deals. Neal emphasized the crucial role that the Panama Canal played in the economic vitality of the Eastern Seaboard. Other than Ross, no one on Trumpâ€™s team seemed aware of this. â€œThey were a bit surprised,â€ Neal later told me. He was also struck by the White Houseâ€™s abhorrence of multilateral pacts, which seemed to him to be naÃ¯ve. â€œThe idea that youâ€™re going to negotiate 148 bilateral agreements with W. T. O. members does not seem realistic,â€ Neal said. â€œThe idea that weâ€™re all of a sudden going to have a   agreement with Great Britain, thatâ€™s going to take years to do. â€ Later, Neal said, Ross privately assured him that the Trump administration â€œwould not give up on multilateral deals. â€ Nealâ€™s lecture signified the start of what is likely to be a long and at times contentious reckoning on the part of Trump and Bannon with the limits of their nationalist rhetoric. Of all the legislative lifts, none will be heavier than renegotiating trade agreements, which require a simple majority approval by both the Senate and the House. Scrounging up 15 Democratic senators who are willing to vote along with 52 Republicans would be a formidable enough task on any issue. But just as Democrats like Neal in the Northeast would fight for a trade deal that benefits their region, so will Republican lawmakers along the Southern border rebel at an effort to repeal Nafta. As McCain told me, â€œIf you negated Nafta, it would send my state into a severe recession. â€ He assured me that Trumpâ€™s nationalist posture would not provoke only regional opposition. He conjured up another Republican era  â€”   not Reaganâ€™s, not Bushâ€™s, but instead that of Herbert Hoover, when two Republican lawmakers joined with a Republican president to design a protectionist initiative that ultimately caused American exports to plummet during the Great Depression. â€œSomewhere,â€ McCain said with a dark chuckle, â€œMr. Smoot and Mr. Hawley are smiling. â€ On Thursday, March 23, Trump hosted a morning meeting of Freedom Caucus holdouts in the Cabinet Room. Jeff Duncan, a congressman from South Carolina who was present, told me that Trump told them: â€œI need you guys. We need to put up a win. Itâ€™s not just about needing to repeal Obamacare  â€”   though we do. Itâ€™s also that a win here sets up a win for tax reform and gives us momentum going into infrastructure. And if the bill fails, it could derail all of that. â€ With customary bravado, Trump told the conservative members that he didnâ€™t want to squeak by with just a   victory. â€œI want all 237 of you,â€ he said, according to Duncan, referring to the entire House Republican conference. That included the more moderate members, who had told Trump they felt that the White House wasnâ€™t paying sufficient attention to their concerns. Later in the day, Trump hosted another meeting with the moderates, where Representative Charlie Dent of Pennsylvania informed Trump that he remained a â€œno. â€ According to an attendee, Trump angrily informed Dent that he was â€œdestroying the Republican Partyâ€ and â€œwas going to take down tax reform  â€”   and Iâ€™m going to blame you. â€ Until that day, Duncan had been an unyielding â€œnoâ€ on the bill. The previous week, he delivered an impassioned speech to the vice president and other Republicans, insisting that this vote constituted â€œour generationâ€™s rendezvous with destiny  â€”   a real chance to roll back the size and scope of the federal government, returning some liberty back to the people through our actions to repeal Obamacare. â€ In a text to me, Duncan pointed to history: â€œ39 men in a hot room in 1787 had the courage to break from the norm and empower a nation. â€ But now the   congressman was, for the first time in his life, sitting across the table from a president who was personally appealing for his support. The White House was offering concessions and agreeing to them in writing. Duncan left the meeting and spent a few hours pondering, as he would later put it, â€œthe greater opportunity we as Republicans have. â€ By that evening, Trump had won Jeff Duncanâ€™s vote. It wasnâ€™t enough. The next afternoon, Ryan pulled the House health care bill, conceding that neither he nor the White House could muster enough votes. â€œYou get about nine months to do the big things,â€ Kevin McCarthy, the House majority leader, told me at the beginning of the year. Nine months seemed like a long time then, the calendar spacious and the legislative   possibilities plentiful. But more than two of those months are gone already  â€”   and the path to future wins, as Trump foresaw in his meeting with the Freedom Caucus, is now more complicated. When he took office, Trump relished the prospect of becoming a new kind of deal maker in the White House. By the time I spoke with him in early March, however, he already seemed to be taking stock of the limits to his powers. He still saw himself as the closer in chief  â€”   but then that was â€œtypical, I would think, of a president,â€ he mused. â€œSome more than others. â€

title: â€™Refuse Fascismâ€™ Group Behind Berkeley Riot Received $50k from George Soros - Breitbart
author: Charlie Nash
text: One of the   â€œ â€ groups behind last weekâ€™s riot in Berkeley, Refuse Fascism, received $50, 000 from a group backed by socialist billionaire George Soros, according to the Daily Caller. [The Alliance for Global Justice, which is funded by the George   Tides Foundation, reportedly donated $50, 000 to fund Refuse Fascism, which openly brags about using violence to shut down conservative and libertarian speech.  â€œWhile it is unclear whether those who carried out the violence were paid to do so, the benefactors of the Alliance for Global Justice  â€”   and Refuse Fascism  â€”   are listed online,â€ reported the Daily Caller. â€œAccording to its most recent 990 tax form, Alliance for Global Justice (AfGJ) received $2. 2 million in funding for the fiscal year ending in March 2016. One of the groupâ€™s biggest donors is the Tides Foundation, a   funded by billionaire progressive philanthropist George Soros. Tides gave AfGJ $50, 000. â€ â€œOther notable donors include the city of Tucson and the United Steel Workers labor union. The former gave $10, 000 to AfGJ while the latter contributed $5, 000,â€ they continued. â€œCharities associated with several major corporations also donated. Patagonia. org, the outdoor apparel and equipment company, gave $40, 000. The Ben  Jerry Foundation, the charity associated with the ice cream maker, gave $20, 000. And Lush Cosmetic gave $43, 950. Another bit of irony is seen in the $5, 000 contribution from the Peace Development Fund, a group that claims to support organizations that fight for human rights and social justice. â€ The group defended the violent riot at Berkeley on Facebook, which left numerous Trump supporters and fans of MILO injured and bloody, before deleting their post. â€œDismantling police fences is not violent,â€ they claimed, according to the Daily Caller, ignoring the rest of the violence that occured. â€œAnd to compare preventing someone like that from speaking to the   violence that they perpetuate everyday is ludicrous. â€ Refuse Fascism also branded the riot as â€œrighteous,â€ and encouraged more violence to shut down conservatives in a post on their website. â€œLast night, thousands of students, professors and others protested the appearance and organizing rally of Milo Yiannopoulos, a major fascist operative, shutting it down. This was righteous and much more like this is needed,â€ the group proclaimed. â€œLets be clear: Milo Yiannopoulos is not engaging in â€˜free speech.â€™ He is consciously spearheading the Nazification of the American University. â€ The riot started at UC Berkeley on Wednesday after protesters against Breitbart Senior Editor MILO became increasingly violent outside of his show. â€œ â€ started several fires, smashed windows and ATMs, looted downtown stores, attacked cars, and assaulted dozens of MILO fans, male and female, who they falsely accused of being â€œNazis. â€ Despite the large amount of violence, numerous reports indicate that police officers refused to intervene, and only one suspect was arrested. UFC veteran and professional MMA fighter Jake Shields was even forced to rescue a man who was being assaulted by   rioters after police allegedly refused to intervene. â€œLike fifteen people were trying to attack him and others were cheering them on,â€ explained Shields, who managed to successfully rescue the man, in an interview with Breitbart News. â€œNo one helped, no one had the balls to step in, so my reaction was to run in and start picking people off. â€ â€œMore chaos started happening, so I went up to the police and tried bringing them back, but they were just like â€˜weâ€™re not really going over there. You should just stay away. â€™â€ he continued. â€œI donâ€™t know if they were taking orders from someone or if they were just being lazy. I donâ€™t know what the situation was, but it was pathetic to watch. Our police, who are supposed to defend the citizens of Berkeley. Itâ€™s a sad scene that they would allow that. â€ The national   for the Alliance for Global Justice, Chuck Kaufman, claimed he wasnâ€™t aware that Refuse Fascism were involved in the riots, but defended their involvement citing the fact that numerous   groups joined in. â€œI wasnâ€™t aware that Refuse Fascism was involved, but probably they were one of a whole lot of groups calling to shut down Milo Yiannopoulosâ€™ hate speech,â€ said Kaufman to The Daily Caller. â€œAfGJ acts as fiscal sponsor for Refuse Fascism which means we process   donations for them. As long as their use of the money falls into areas permitted for   501( c)(3) organizations, we donâ€™t involve ourselves one way or the other in their program work. â€ Several celebrities and news outlets expressed support for the riot, including Hollywood director Judd Apatow, who deleted his tweet shortly after, and Fusion, who smeared MILO as a â€œNazi,â€ before praising rioters. The day after, MILOâ€™s tour bus was tracked down by â€œ â€ and vandalized, forcing both him and his team to evacuate the premises after his location was leaked online. Four   were also arrested last week after they became violent during a protest against libertarian commentator and VICE   Gavin McInnes, who was speaking at New York University. DANGEROUS is available to   now via Amazon, in hardcover and Kindle editions. And yes, MILO is reading the audiobook version himself!  Charlie Nash is a reporter for Breitbart Tech. You can follow him on Twitter @MrNashington or like his page at Facebook.

title: Liberals Setting Up a Pass on Colin Kapernickâ€™s NFL Free Agency as Evidence of â€™Racismâ€™ - Breitbart
author: Warner Todd Huston
text: As more members of the media discover that San Francisco 49ers   quarterback Colin Kaepernickâ€™s free agency is going ignored by the NFL, many are pegging his failure an example of â€œracism. â€[Kaepernick became the subject of both praise and condemnation last season with his   protests, by refusing to stand for the playing of the national anthem at the start of each game. After the season, the quarterback declared his free agency but with the announcement also announced an abrupt end to his refusal to stand for the anthem. But, with the leagueâ€™s free agents signing to teams at a quickening pace, Kaepernick has thus far gone unsigned.  Only last week, Bleacher Reportâ€™s Mike Freeman took a look at Kaepernickâ€™s inability to find a new team and noted that many executives donâ€™t want his type of disruption in their locker rooms. Over the weekend, a Fox News article revealed that â€œ70 percent of NFL managers genuinely hateâ€ Colin Kaepernick. Many reasons have been listed. Some analysts criticize Kaepernickâ€™s throwing accuracy, others think he isnâ€™t much of a team player because he is a moody loner, and still others say he seems out of his depth when asked to learn new plays and plans. Rumors circled early in the season that Kaepernick only began his protests to raise his profile as a race activist to head off being traded by the 49ers. This rumor charged that Kaepernick meant use his activism as a weapon against the team, so that in case they tried to trade him he could claim racism. And in that vein, it appears that some in the media fell right into line with that tactic. TV One host and former CNN personality Roland Martin is a case in point. Martin made just that very charge in a March 17 tweet. If not a single @NFL team signs @Kaepernick7, it shows their hatred of a Black man taking a social stand. These execs are pathetic.  â€”   rolandsmartin (@rolandsmartin) March 17, 2017,  By not signing @Kaepernick7, these @NFL teams are sending a signal to their players: Donâ€™t you dare use your voice. We own you!  â€”   rolandsmartin (@rolandsmartin) March 17, 2017,  The fired CNNer isnâ€™t alone. Activist filmmaker Spike Lee also called the NFLâ€™s refusal to hire Kaepernick an example of â€œracism. â€ Just Had Brunch With My Brother Colin @Kaepernick7 . How Is It That There Are 32 NFL Teams And Kap Is Still A Free Agent? WTF. Smells MAD Fishy To Me, Stinks To The High Heavens. The New York     Need A Quarterback. Who Is The     Quarterback? Is My Man Joe Willie Namath Coming Back? Crazy Times We Live In. The Question Remains What Owner And GM Is Going To Step Up And Sign Colin So Their Team Has A Better Chance To WIN? What Crime Has Colin Committed? Look At The QBâ€™s Of All 32 Teams. This Is Some Straight Up Shenanigans, Subterfuge, Skullduggery And BS.  ?  . By Any Means Necessary. And Datâ€™s Da NoFunLeague Truth, Ruth. A post shared by Spike Lee (@officialspikelee) on Mar 19, 2017 at 2:10pm PDT,  The claim that Kaepernick is being punished because he is black or outspoken has been taken up by many in an effort to use him for their own activist purposes. . @ShannonSharpe: The NFL owners are sending a message. By punishing Colin Kaepernick, they are deterring others from taking such acts. pic. twitter.   â€”   UNDISPUTED (@undisputed) March 20, 2017,  . @MichaelSam52 came out  heâ€™s out of NFL. @brendon310  @ChrisWarcraft support gay rights  are gone. @Kaepernick7 took knee  is unsigned.  â€”   Hari Kondabolu (@harikondabolu) March 11, 2017,  @TheEconomist tell that to the conservatives who crucified colin kaepernick â€”  for having the temerity to kneel.  â€”   Gordon Ballingrud (@gdb50001) March 10, 2017,  The NFL proved how racist it is with its lack of support for #ColinKaepernick. To be honest it will be hard for  â€¦     https:  .   â€”   Jackie Rae (@JRaethefanatic) March 20, 2017,  Follow Warner Todd Huston on Twitter @warnerthuston or email the author at igcolonel@hotmail. com.

title: Hacker Claims To Have Stolen These Controversial Photos From NASA
author: Eddy Lavine
text: posted by Eddie The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has always been at the frontier of science and technology. Since 1958, NASA has done its best to allow humankind to know more about life and the universe. Thanks to this space agency, people have been able to walk on the moon. In the near future, we might even have people walking on Mars. NASA will be moving farther into the unknown areas of the Universe. I know that many of us are hoping to find life beyond the earth. But what if NASA is already aware of alien life ? Well, one hacker claims to have found NASAâ€™s secret photos for all the world to see. Read on! 1. Is that a massive wheel from an extinct civilization? This could have possibly been a part of a huge machine. 2. The side of this cliff has been charred. This shouldnâ€™t look like this if this portion was a representation of what occurred thousands of years ago. Is this because of extraterrestrial activity? 3. This metal vault was hidden in ice for so long. I want to know whatâ€™s inside this mysterious container! 4. Is this place from another planet? If you look closely, the area beyond shows a structure that doesnâ€™t look like anything on the earth. 5. These golden bricks hide an unknown language. Sadly, no one has been able to decipher what these writings mean. 6. What were all those military ships doing there? Either they were observing a supernatural phenomenon, or they were trying a new military weapon. 7. Did NASA hide this asteroid impact from the public? If they did, they must have good reason to keep it away from everyone else. Did they witness extraterrestrial life? 8. Those holes donâ€™t look natural at all. The circles are almost the same, and the placement is strange. It looks like a place where machines are hidden and deployed. 9. Using night vision, NASA supposedly captured an unknown structure. It looks like a pyramid, but it is not visible using normal cameras. 10. Was this huge skeleton a part of the Anunnaki? The Anunnaki was known in Mesopotamia as a group of Gods. 11. Large human beings probably existed at some point. However, why canâ€™t scientists find something like this today? This creature might have been an alien that looks like a human. 12. I found this image incredibly terrifying! If this is true, then NASA has evidence of extraterrestrial life. That obviously looks like a spaceship. 13. A temple was found underneath the ocean. title: Mark Ruffalo Just Did Something Amazing For Protesters Fighting the Dakota Access Pipeline
author: Tom Cahill
text:
27444 SHARES 
The Standing Rock Siouxâ€™s camp, set up to physically stop construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline, just got solar power thanks to Mark Ruffalo. 
The actor and director delivered trailers full of solar panels alongside Wahleah Johns, founder of Native Renewables, to the Standing Rock camp. As cold weather begins to set in for the indigenous tribes facing off with oil companies in North Dakota, the solar panels will help generate electricity to provide the camp with life-sustaining heat and medical treatment. 
EcoWatch reported that Ruffalo and Johns touted the necessity of switching to renewable energy in the wake of drastic climate change. Ruffalo also emphasized the right of Native Americans to protect their land from predatory fossil fuel companies. 
â€œAround the world, more than 80 percent of the forests and lands with protected waterways and rich biodiversity are held by indigenous tribes. This is no coincidence,â€ Ruffalo said. â€œAs so many of us suffer from polluted water, air and land in our rural and urban communities, the water defenders at Standing Rock are showing us another way.â€ 
However, Ruffalo was quick to note that he was merely â€œtrying to be of serviceâ€ in using his platform to bring awareness to the Dakota Access Pipeline protest. 
â€œIt was really Wahleah Johns responsible for the delivery. I was there to draw the spotlight,â€ Ruffalo told US Uncut in an email. 
Johns, whose companyâ€™s goal is to provide low-cost, renewable energy sources and green energy jobs for indigenous communities, praised the Standing Rock Siouxâ€™s fight against Energy Transfer Partnersâ€™ pipeline, calling it necessary for the sake of the planetâ€™s survival. 
â€œWater is life,â€ said Johns , who is a leader in the Navajo nation. â€œBy leading a transition to energy that is powered by the sun, the wind, and water, we ensure a better future for all of our people and for future generations.â€ 
The Dakota Access Pipeline, if constructed, would carry highly toxic tar sands oil through North Dakota, South Dakota, Iowa, and Illinois , where it would then be transported by train to ports on the Gulf of Mexico. Sacred land belonging to indigenous communities in North Dakota was destroyed for the pipeline route, with Native American leaders saying they were never consulted about the pipeline before construction began. The Standing Rock Sioux, who call themselves â€œwater protectors,â€ say the pipeline would endanger drinking water for millions of people along the pipeline route. 

Tom Cahill is a writer for US Uncut based in the Pacific Northwest. He specializes in coverage of political, economic, and environmental news. You can contact him via email at [email protected]

title: Study: More Vitamin B In Motherâ€™s Diet Reduces Risk Of Colon Cancer In Offspring
author: Dr. Edward F. Group III
text:
in: General Health (image: shutterstock) Few experts question the influence a motherâ€™s diet can have on her childrenâ€™s long term physical health. Yet, many believe this effect is mostly sociological, limited to positive or negative role modeling, and the development of general dietary habits later in life. However, research suggests that the foods moms eat could impact the health of their children much more directly. Scientists at Tufts Universityâ€™s USDA Human Nutrition Research Center on Aging (USDA HNRCA), near Boston, have published findings of a study which shows a strong connection between the quantity of B vitamins pregnant mice consume and the likelihood of their offspring developing colorectal cancer as adults [ 1 ] . Breaking Down The Study Three test groups of pregnant and nursing mice, which were genetically engineered to be predisposed to develop colorectal cancer, were fed diets with either higher than normal, adequate, or slightly deficient amounts of folate and vitamins B2, B6, and B12. Once fully weened, all newborn mice were fed identical, nutritionally balanced diets through adulthood. The occurrence of tumor development appeared similar between both the adequate and B vitamin deficient groups, with about 60 percent of the mice in each of these two groups eventually developing colon cancer . In comparison, less than 20 percent of the mice in the group that was given larger than normal servings of B vitamins were found to have malignant growths. While these figures are impressive, the researchers caution that the study itself is only a preliminary investigation, and additional studies will be needed to further assess the correlation between maternal vitamin B consumption and reduced risk of cancer in humans. 
Dr. Jimmy Crott, PhD, lead author of the HNRCA study: 
â€œWe saw, by far, the fewest intestinal tumors in the offspring of mothers consuming the supplemented diet. Although the tumor incidence was similar between offspring of deficient and adequate mothers, 54% of tumors in the deficient offspring were advanced and had invaded surrounding tissue while only 18% of tumors in the offspring of adequate mothers displayed these aggressive properties.â€ Most healthcare providers already recommend higher than normal intake of folate and other essential B vitamins during pregnancy and while nursing as part of routine prenatal care. And accordingly, most popular brands of prenatal vitamins> contain significantly larger than normal serving of all four B vitamins as compared to regular multivitamins. The standard reasons for this, however, have nothing to do with with the prevention of colon cancer. In addition to their potential for the risk of colorectal cancer, Vitamin B â€“ folate, more specifically â€“ has long been known to play an important role in the prevention of spina bifida and related defects of the neural tube (a sort of embryonic forerunner of the central nervous system) during fetal gestation. Itâ€™s also believed to have a strong influence on proper neurological development in very young children. References:

title: Daily Mail Compares 2 U.K. Leaders â€” Their Legs, Not Their Ideas - The New York Times
author: Sewell Chan
text: LONDON  â€”   Britainâ€™s prime minister and Scotlandâ€™s leader met on Monday to discuss the most consequential of questions: Will Britainâ€™s departure from the European Union cause Scotland  â€”   joined with England since 1707  â€”   to leave the United Kingdom? But for The Daily Mail, one of Britainâ€™s most popular newspapers, the question that mattered was: Which leader had better legs? â€œNever mind Brexit, who won  !â€ its cover on Tuesday blared. Many readers were appalled that the encounter between Theresa May, the prime minister, and Nicola Sturgeon, the first minister of Scotland, had been reduced to a comparison of their bodies.
